South Bronx Academy for Applied Media is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

What happened to IS 184?  I graduated in 1990.  For the most part, we were an economically disadvantaged group. However, we were very well behaved students.  Throughout the three years as a student my experiences were very positive.  Some of my best teachers were in IS 184.
IS 184 closed in 2008. A couple of new schools were opened in the 184 building. http://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/23/education/23EDUCATION.html?_r=0

State Education Commisioner Richard Mills announced in August that the South Bronx Academy for Applied Media has been removed from the state's list of  "persistently dangerous" schools for the 2008-2009 school year.

"In the New York Times article "How a Middle School Can Be 'Dangerous' And Still Get an A," New York Time wrtier, Samuel Freedman does not tell the complete story, failing to mention that two of the three former teachers interviewed were teaching in a middle school for the first time last year. None are teaching in a middle school this year," writes teacher Dmitry A. Terekhov. "Unfortunately, it was not the right setting for them. The lack of compatibility between their personalities and the ages of their students mixed with a lack of middle school experience served many times to exacerbate the behavior problems described. Interviewing three disgruntled ex-teachers does not do reality justice and although Mr. Freedman was encouraged to visit the school this year, he chose not to. Visiting the school last Thursday was the State Education Department, there due to our classification as "persistently dangerous." After meeting with focus groups of students, teachers and parents, the report made was favorable, with no safety concerns issued. How in the face of adversity 13 out of 16 first year teachers managed to raise test scores to an A level should be celebrated, not questioned."

According to a December 19, 2007 New York Times article by Samuel G. Freedman, although the school received an A on it's progress reports, for raising test scores of the lowest performing students, and bilingual and special education students, "In a survey conducted last year by the City Department of Education, 98 percent of Applied Media's students said there was fighting in the school, 94 percent said there was bullying and 67 percent said they were worried about crime and violence in the school."... a digital camera and a cellphone were stolen...[...]

"I didn't teach last year," Ms. Staples said. "I was a police officer and a baby sitter. You'd write up kids left and right, and then nothing would happen. No one would help you. And the kids would just come right back. After I got hit, the principal's response was, 'That's what happens in middle schools.'" [...]

"The principal, Roshone Ault, said she supported teachers in disciplinary matters by bringing in experts in "social-emotional learning" to train the faculty and was offering students incentives like pizza parties for good behavior." [...]

"Dmitry Terekhov, a teacher, said: "'The A we received is a testament to the teachers. We got the job done.'" However, he also stated: "No principals want to be where we are," he said. "No teachers want to be where we are. It's too hard."
South Bronx Academy has been added to the state's list of "persistently dangerous" schools, meaning that for two years the school has reported a high ratio of violent incidents to students.

"While the principal is a hard, dedicated worker who cares about her students, I do not believe that Ms. Ault was an effective manager last year," writes a teacher who complains that Principal Ault was "unwilling to hear the grievances that were made by the staff" and that discipline was "unchecked." This teacher also notes that the school possessed only limited media equipment.

Principal Roshone Ault responds: "SBAAM is committed to providing a quality education in a small safe, disciplined and caring environment where student scholars and adults are meaningfully engaged in learning. During the 2005-2006 academic year, we experienced many school wide and classroom discipline challenges which is not unusual for a first-year school. All reported disciplinary concerns were immediately addressed. It is unfortunate that a former teaching 'professional' who was reprimanded claims to be the voice of all staff members.

"As a new small school we did not have the financial resources to purchase new technological equipment in our first year; such equipment was shared with the other schools in the building. At the end of the school year, Council Member Maria Del Carmen Arroyo awarded a significant sum of money to the school to purchase equipment due to the success of our first documentary film festival."

Ault also notes that the school's recent Quality Review includes the following statements in the section 'What the school does well': 'There is a shared understanding of the school vision, which is supported by staff and scholars,' 'Teamwork is strong with agreement over the school's core values and consistency in the way staff are working to realize them,' and 'The principal has good capacity to effect change, and the vision and passion she has for her school is evident in all she does.'"

Responding to the school's profile, PrincipaI Roshone Ault writes: "I would say that the major 'downside' is that scholars are not fully included due to self contained classes. Across the board, children's academic skills are improving drastically. I do not think it is a true reflection to state that their skills are poor on a whole."
"We get to go on a lot of trips, to Yankee Stadium, to the Bronx Zoo," said 6th grader Antonio, 12. "Ms. Ault cares about the community and she wants to make it better."
"I love being here," said Michelle L'Eplattenier, the media arts teacher. "The students are extremely independent and very creative and very aware of the world."

Academy of Public Relations is among 40 middle schools selected for an extension of the Middle School Quality Initiative, a program that increases professional development on Common Core-aligned literacy strategies and gives targeted funding for literacy training and materials. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

Let me say that the Academy of Public Relations is a school in a class all by itself!!  As a former student I cannot believe that there are people on this thread that are saying anything negative about this school.  They must not know the school because the school I remember is not like that.  The teachers are the best and what I mean by this is that they are always making sure you understand and are always available (or make themselves available) to help students learn.  Ms. Andino and Mr. Marks are truly like a "mom" and "pop".  How many schools can say that for students in the South Bronx let alone the entire NYC??  You walk into this school and you know the adults care about you.  It is thanks to them that I attend Manhattan Center of Math and Science.  My mother did not want me to attend school outside of the Bronx and Ms. Andino made an appoinmetn with my mother to make sure that my mother understands that I don't only have to attend high school near the Bronx.  She told my mother that there is a whole world that is out there and I need to see it.  It was hard in the begining but I thank my lucky stars that Ms. Andino took the time to meet with my mother so I can be where I am today.  What principals do you know that would do the same?  I will always remember my teachers, my friends and everyone that made my experience there so special.  I love APR forever!

"Since September of 2008, I have been an after-school vocal music instructor for the Academy of Public Relations. During my years of teaching, rarely have I encountered a school with such bright, well-adjusted students, eager to learn, and eager for excellence as they are at APR. Principal Amy Andino and her Assistant Principal Barry Marx deserve a lion's share of the credit for this scholastic triumph. With their tireless dedication to the educational, emotional, and psychological well-being of their students, these youngsters' futures look brighter every day. The energy, humor, and enthusiasm of the school's teaching staff is tangible, seeming to radiate even from the building's quiet, empty corridors. It has been my honor, my privilege, indeed my personal pleasure to be involved with the staff and students of the Academy of Public Relations."

"Most teachers here really do care about the students and help them achieve high academically," writes a student. "They encourage you to do better and will give a lot of their time to you when you need it. The school is also small compared to other ones which lets everyone know each other and become more close. It also allows teachers to give more of their time to more of their students which is a big plus."

"Each teacher dedicated 110% of their time to us; this eventually encouraged students to aim high and also lead in preventing a substantial amount of drop-outs from happening," writes former student Rafael Castro, who credits the school for making him "the great person" he is today. "The complexity of having more student than school space and the effort put in by trying to maintain a school open even by using trailers to teach students the necessary knowledge to carry on a successful future clearly showed the caring and dedication contributed by school officials and students while maintaining proficiency levels at high standards. Hostos Lincoln Academy of Science H.S is number one."

"I strongly believe that Hostos Lincoln Academy of Science is better then famous schools like Bronx Science, and Stuyvesant," writes a student. "I say this with confidence because Hostos offers a warm and comfortable environment. Teachers know our names, even if they never taught us a class. We notice, and we help. Hostos will always be great and successful. The board of ed needs to leave us alone though. No need to change us. All from Hostos know what I mean."

Bronx Academy of Letters rising senior Lisa Parks and recent graduate Matthew Diaz were awarded the Billie Jean King Youth Leadership Award at this year's Sports Humanitarian Awards (ESPYs), NYLPI reports. As members of the Fair Play Coalition, they drew attention to the unequal access to sports that Black and Latino youth face, served as lead plaintiffs in a lawsuit against the DOE and lobbied the state legislature to pass a law that will shed light on these inequities.

Urban Assembly Bronx Academy of Letters is on a list of 50 schools that will participate in the DOE's Bronx Plan, which will boost salaries in hard-to-staff positions and "give teachers formal decision-making power in their schools" according to Chalkbeat.

Urban Assembly Bronx Academy of Letters students Lisa Parks and Matthew Diaz joined a class action lawsuit against the DOE and PSAL alleging that the city violated the human rights of black and Latino students by denying them equal access to sports teams, as Chalkbeat reports.

I could go on and on about Bronx Letters, but instead will do my best to keep it short: this is a magical place. It isn't perfect (is anything?) but what is important is that it's trying to be. I have been a part of the community for many years and can attest that it has done nothing but improve year after year. A comment further below stated the changes that they disagree with - I can absolutely say that they are a disgruntled person making waves, because all of those changes were 100% for the better, or at the very least necessary. 

The learning happening in classrooms here isn't just about gathering information, it's about learning where we stand in the world. Every class pushes students to think about what is happening right now in our world, and what sort of impact it has on them and they can have on it. Students and teachers work alongside each other to better understand what is going on, rather than teachers acting like they are all-knowing gifts to the class. There are opportunities for students to push one another, to better work with their community, to design the kind of learning and activities that they care about. But Letters is much more than a school, because the people within it care about more than just curriculum - they care about kids. To hear both students and teachers say that the community feels like a family is a normal occurrence, and every student has adults that they are close with. As each year passes more and more 8th graders choose to stay for four more years, and alumni are seen visiting on a regular basis. 

It's hard to keep this any shorter, because there is literally that much to say about the school and the people within it. There are plenty of amazing schools in NYC, but none like Bronx Letters - because it isn't just a school, it's a home.

This school is a really great school! I am a student here and I love it. Tell me how many schools can you text the principal when you have a problem or learn about whats happening at school from instagram or hang out with your English teacher after school to get quiet space for homework or go to Ms. Lidia when you're looking for a job or a study abroad program or sign up for sports or take overnight college trips or join the debate team or go to protests? The school is great and I've been here since middle school so I can tell you how much the staff cares about this school and how hard the principal and assistant principals work to make sure we are getting what we need. The rules are annoying sometimes but they are all pretty normal stuff like uniforms, passes, lateness, attendance, and all that stuff. The deans go hard for the school and yes, sometimes it is really annoying but that's why our results keep going up! The school has changed a lot over the last few years and change is hard. But there is no question if this is a great school and if the staff here cares about us. These are people who call me to wake up for school. These are people who come to your house if you are missing days. I get that some people want a more chill environment but as a student, I prefer a place with high standards that will prepare me for college. This is that school. The staff is fire. The focus is on social justice which means the focus is on us! I am a headed into my senior year and I am a different person because I went here.

You know you are at an amazing school when all you can think about is going back to the community during the summer time. I started at BAL just as any first-year teacher starts, timid and in need of support. However, I quickly realized the sort of space I was in and the people I was surrounded by. I found myself working with a team of teachers who were ready and able to help me reflect on my craft (lesson planning, procedures, etc.) while helping me understand how to build relationships with the students. The student-teacher relationships I was able to develop were even further supported by an administration, who worked daily to analyze the culture and ensure the entire community had space to comfortably learn and work..... and this was only the first year. The principal and other leaders are constantly reflecting on the school every year (with heavy input from students and staff) and seamlessly builds supports where they are needed. They have brought on more administrators to support teachers, more counselors to help support students emotionally, more special education teachers to help ensure all students get the education they deserve and more leadership roles for students to ensure they have a strong voice. The two greatest gains have been made in the restorative justice program (half the rate of other NYC schools,) and the thriving sports program (city champs in softball!) All of this (and more) have made this school become a true home to everyone who walks in the doors. Yes, we do face the same challenges as many other schools, but I can confidently stand up to them with the support of absolutely everyone around me on a foundation built by people who care.

The Principal is amazing!! he is very helpful when it comes to anything that would better the school and kids. He ensures that restorative justice practices are applied in all we do. I am currently a teacher at BAL and can honestly say it is he best school I have worked at. The scholars best interest are always put first and the staff always comes together to make sure we are providing them with the best opportunities possible. Our scholars are exposed to colleges from grade 6 and have over night and day trips to different colleges throughout the school year. They are taught how to use their voices to make sure they make changes in their communities. Our scholars have gone to DC to states their opinions and have gone to places such as facebook headquarters to attempt to block videos of people fighting. They have taken a stand in so many issues that our nation is going through such as day of silence for those whom don't have a voice and the nationwide walk out that was organized by our own students. 

I have never been at a school in which observations are actually a positive experience. Every de-brief is filled with amazing feed back and actual attainable next steps that the Principal Brandon Cardet and the 2 AP's Erin and Amy give you things they have used when they where teachers to help you out. They will also take the time to plan with you if you need help and are the teachers biggest cheerleaders in the classroom. I actually looked forward to my observations because I knew I was going to learn something new in de-brief. They also encourage teachers to apply to leadership positions throughout the school and even if you don't have experience they help you. 

They are also amazing with first year teachers. hey encourage first year teachers and give them the best guidance ever. I never had this guidance when I was a first year teacher so I asked to be put on so I could experience it and I loved it. They give you extra observations and don't expect you to know it all as other schools would. They build you up in the best way and help you find your groove. 

The Principal and the support staff are always out in the hallways during transition and can be seen giving students pep talks when they need it, intervening in issues long before they get out of hand, and implementing rules and regulations of the school in the most honest way. The school has a counselor for every grade which is amazing as the counselors know every student personally. The counselors are committed to make sure the students stay on the right path and when students don't show up do home visits to attempt to figure out the problem. 

The school is a big fighter to get more money for sports in lower income segregated communities like ours. Our students have gone and spoken at many different places to present this case and state how important it is for schools in segregated communities to have access to sports programs. Our female softball team came out number 1 in the city championships this year and this shows how dedicated they where and the staff was to helping them go above and beyond. 

The principal has an open door policy, when he is in his office, and students and staff feel free to always be able to walk in and talk to him if they have an issue. The principal is very transparent to what expectations are for both students and staff and has many ways to help you maintain expectations. 

Every year the school host a benefit to help raise money for events and trips that the DOE doesn't provide funding for such as over night college trips outside of the state. In which students stay in hotels while they tour colleges. Our school also has an exchange program in which our students go for one week to another state to stay at a participating students home and go to school with them. Then the following year that students comes to the bronx and attends BAL. 

The staff is mixed with different cultures and ages of people whom have the best interest of the students in mind always. They students can be seen asking for hugs and asking staff to help them with personal issues since they feel such a strong connection with us. We are def one big family. 

One amazing difference at this school is that they understand that you are human and have families. When I had to leave when my son got sick in school, I found that I was giving smiles by the administration to go and take care of him instead of mean stares. 

One of the AP's, Erin Garry, even set up an additional English regents prep course at the end of the year in which I had the privilege to help her teach. She would still do her AP job but also would lesson plan for over a month to make sure our students were getting additional help. 

Brandon is big on us also looking at ourselves and doing work on ourselves that don't have to do with teaching. During our PD's we did cultural work to notice our own biases and experiences with discrimination and racism so that we may better serve our students. We as a staff were able to bond and get to know each other as more than just co-workers but as individuals. This gave us an upper hand since we were able to tackle issues together instead of separately. 

I would recommend this school to anyone. It is lots of work since you are always working on yourself and your students but it is an amazing experience. I have grown as a teacher more in this school that all my years of teaching combined.

Principal Brandon Cardet-Hernandez is a politician and does not leave Instagram or his office. He is not a Principal. He relies on the head of school culture, a dean, Mr. David Rosen-Garcia, to run the school and it’s become more like Rikers than using restorative practices to promote social justice. This is evident in the suspension rates, which consistently lead the Urban Assembly. 

Cardet-Hernandez has forced out incredible counselors, teachers and support staff for personal reasons, regardless of their work and dedication to the school and community. Any staff that consistently put the interest of the kids first - Ms. Dash, Ms. Chapman, Ms. A, Mr. Rekoert - were either fired or
told to leave. They’re no longer there. Neither are the most unifying aspects of the BAL community - Advisory, Houses, Founders Day, the Applegate Garden, Field Day, the Annual Thanksgiving Feast... 
The heart of Bronx Letters is gone. 

There used to be a sense of family within the school building. Now, it’s a cutthroat environment where students and staff are held to different standards, depending on how much the Principal and the dean like you. It isn’t right. It is damaging the culture of what once was a special place for the South Bronx community.

The Urban Assembly Bronx Academy of Letters is a part of the DOE's Single Shepherd program, which has placed additional counselors and social workers in New York City's neediest school districts, Chalkbeat reports.
Good school in a bad area. Lots of programs and great trips for students. They have their own organic garden run by Ms. A. Looks like the school is on an upward trend.

New York City Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced on June 16, 2016 that the Bronx Academy of Letters will be one of the first 100 schools in the city to be part of College Access for All. Schools in this program will receive $3.5 million in direct funding to help ensure that students graduate with clear college and career plans by 2018.
Students in the group IntegrateNYC4, founded by the school, have spent more than a year exploring segregation and possible solutions. SchoolBook reports.
The Bronx Academy of Letters advisory board has helped the school become a fundraising powerhouse, reports DNAinfo.

BAL's Brandon Cardet-Hernandez is one of 36 New York City principals who are calling for Governor Andrew Cuomo to pay $2 billion they say city schools are owed following a lawsuit in 2006, reports Chalkbeat.

The school is really great! This year has been fantastic and I couldn't be happier that my daughter is a student there. The teachers are really dedicated and I get phones calls that are positive all the time. The school principal (Brandon Cardet-Hernandez) is outside every morning greeting kids by name and hurrying kids into the school! A great place. I will make sure my son in elementary school goes to Bronx Academy of Letters. I wish more parents were engaged but the school offers a lot of opprotunities including college trips every semester and tons of after school programs
At BAL, an elective class on integration gives students a voice in in the ongoing public discussion about race, class and New York City schools. Read more here.
Hear a WNYC Schoolbook piece on the integration class here.

Feeling so lucky that my kid attends BAL. I just went to the school sat with the principal, Brandon, and looked over my students transcript to talk about the future, his strengths and how I can support. There has been a lot of change at the school (especially some key staffing changes) and it goes without saying that I think this is for the better. Looks like some of the comments are from angry teachers who needed to move on and can't seem to let go. 

Anyway- a great place. Lots of activities, caring staff, college opportunities and a big focus on the whole child. I even just got to meet the new college counselor and I could not be more excited about what's to come for our community.

I am a parent at Bronx Letters. The school is a different place in just one short year with Brandon as principal. He hardly works (seriously, he is always out and the place tends to run itself) and is creating a school that does not help kids but instead tokenizes them for fundraising purposes. It is also clear that he lacks focus although he talks an awful lot about college. He has harmed the school by getting a significant number of experienced teachers and staff to find other schools for employment for 2015 - 2016. BAL was a beacon in the South Bronx and under new leadership the school is simply circling the drain.

I am a parent at Bronx Letters. The school is a different place in just one short year with Brandon as principal. He works so hard to create a school that does not vilify kids but instead helps them become better. It is also clear that his focus is on instruction and making sure students are ready for college. He has helped the school by getting a significant number of grants and fundraising to build out programs for our kids. BAL is a beacon in the South Bronx and under new leadership, the school is back and better than ever.

This school is 29% Black and 69% hispanic when one focuses on the student body but what about the teachers? The Urban Assembly should hire more Black and hispanic teachers for Bronx Academy of Letters. Don't get me wrong as a graduate of this school I have nothing against the majority of teachers who happen to be white there. They care a lot about the students but I also realize now looking back that the majority of the teachers were white women and the school functioned like a cadre of missionaries with an air of charity. This was highlighted by the annual fundraisers where we were invited to prance around or stand on stage as if on an auction block. It would be good if they could use that money to attract and support more minority teachers. I'd like to go back and teach there one day if it can stay true to the mission and vision it had while I was there and have a faculty that reflects the population it serves.

I used to stare at the Edgar Allen Poe quote: "Deep into that darkness peering, long I stood there, wondering, fearing, doubting, dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before" and wax poetic in my mind about the possibilities this place is imbued with. This quote eventually adorned our very own library. The Bronx Academy of Letters sounds like an incredible place and believe me it was. The founding principal was a powerful force and we all worked our tails off to meet her expectations. 


This very many years later I feel I am stuck in another extreme of Poe's writing. I'm left scratching my head, thinking "words have no power to impress the mind without the exquisite horror of their reality." (Poe, again) And in many ways I am silent, speechless, going with the flow, trying to keep my head above water, while trying to fly below the radar. I don't know who will hear (or read) my words or if they will see the light of day. I cannot find the words that can comprehensibly describe this horror show and hope this post gives others courage to share their multiple perspectives in order to save this place from itself. 


How did we move from a founding principal who got it, and pushed all of us, whether we liked her or not, to be our better selves, to this fourth principal, in a short 12 years, who most of us don't like although he tries so hard to be likable, who doesn't get any of it, and pushed us all to become our worst selves? How have we all allowed one person, or possibly a pair, pull so much apart?
YES. So true! 3 years later.

Students at the Bronx Academy of Letters are choosing to skip lunch rather than eat cafeteria food they say is inedible. A group of students is raising awareness of the issue through a new group IntegrateNYC4me. Read more here.

The principal of the school said my child belongs in a mental institution. How dare he make a remark like that about a student with an IEP! I wouldn't recommend this school to any other parents based on my interactions with the leaders of the school.

We ask because after about 20 days missing in action in the first 4 months of principalship we are left wondering where in the world is Brandon Cardet-Hernandez? Will he ever step up and be present at BAOL or are we just a part of his dog and pony show?

Samantha, student at the Bronx Academy of Letters, has been thinking a lot about diversity in the wake of the Ferguson, Mo., shooting of an unarmed black teen by a white police officer, she believes segregated schools like hers are one root of the problem. Read more here.

every year the bronx letters community would come together and celebrate as a family with a feast up until this year. we have a new principal and it is his way or the highway. he doesn't listen to the parents wishes and for that reason i am glad my child is graduating this year and won't have to deal with any more of the changes at this school that i used to think was such a good school. on this thanksgiving i am thankful for that.

This is a bloomberg created small wasted school and it even boasts the fact that eva moskowitz charter is there to live with ya every daY.  KNOCK YOUR SELF OUT IF YOU GO HERE

GothamSchools profiles Anna Hall, former principal of Bronx Academy of Letters, in her new position as education director of StudentsFirstNY, a "spinoff of Michelle Rhee’s national education advocacy group." Hall said she will focus on improving teacher quality, a goal that includes pushing an end to seniority-based layoffs and teacher tenure.

GothamSchools reports that Shael Polakow-Suransky, the second in command at the Education Department, visited Bronx School of Letters during teacher appreciation week and guest-taught an AP English class.

Bronx School of Letters graduated 83.1 percent of their eligible students, but only 19.1 percent were ready for college, according to their progress reports for the 2010-11 school year. Read more: At Most High Schools, Fewer Than Half of Graduates Are Ready for College.

Bronx Academy of Letters is a beacon of quality education in the South Bronx. The teachers and staff go above and beyond the status quo to provide students with instruction that will prepare them for college and life beyond the halls of high school. With enrichment programs, interesting clubs for kids such as Brazilian Jujitsu, and a beautiful library, Letters stands out for it's attempt to develop the whole child and connect him or her with the world.

This school has changed dramatically since the departure of its founding principal.  The new principal seems out of touch and prefers to keep a large team of administrators rather than supports for students.

This needs updating. The administration - principal and assistant principals - have certainly gotten their finger on the pulse of the school both in terms of staff and student needs. This year is flowing much, much more smoothly than last year.

As a parent of a sixth grader I see excitement in his eyes when he has to get up on a tired morning of school. At dismissal he rattles on about what he has learned and what upcoming opportunities are open. He especially loves reading and appreciates having free access to the library at anytime even in the mornings before class starts. The young people here are typical for their age yet by the time they go into the school they have left foolishness outside. So far I judge this school not by reports but by the attitude of the students. I give it an A-.  They need a more organized PTA with multi language support as well as mandated parental involvement.
By the time he reaches the end of 7th grade trust me he'll probably want to be taken out of the school

"As a high school mathematics substitue teacher, upon entry into the school a parent of an elementary student became disruptive with the safety agent over presenting an ID. Classes were about 20-25 students. Students overall were cooperative, friendly and focused on work. A poet of Etriean and Hispanic influence conducted a reading of her poetry and talk after school. All students were mandated to attend. Students also showed off their poetry and writing skills. An assistant principal scolded a child for misbehavior in the classroom but was smiling at the time. I felt he could have been a little more serious about discipline."
"This school has given me tremendous opportunities," writes student Rohanie. "Every student gets the special one-on-one attention they need."
Amanda, a student, writes: "This school is so great because it has small classes and students get lots of attention. We have a lot of fun and we're all together!"

"Joan [Sullivan] is the hardest working person I've ever met," said a teacher. "She sees the gaps and finds a way to fill them."

The principal has "a vision of what to do, not only for the students but also for the staff," said a teacher who is part of the Teaching Fellows programs that recruits new teachers from other professions. He said the principal is often in his classroom and gives him useful advice. "I get more feedback than any of the fellows in my cohort," he said.
The overview says there are no arts, but through the Community Schools initiative,  there in fact are programs in Theater, Guitar, and Technology, and sometimes dance and more.

PS 14 conducted a training on autism for almost all the school’s teachers before the start of the school year, according to the News12 The Bronx. The three-hour session focused on ways to deal with thechallenges that accompany autism such as sensitivities to light, lack of social cues and atypical interests.

The mosaic in PS 14's lobby has been recognized as one of America's best public arts projects, the Bronx Times reports. The work, "The Tree Inside Me" by Sandy Litchfield, depicts trees, leaves, birds, butterflies and flower in harmony with various buildings and structures.
PS 14 participates in WNBC’s Weather Kids program, Erica Grow from NBC New York’s Storm Team 4 visited, the Bronx Times reports.

PS 14 has been named a NYC Community Learning School as part of an United Federation of Teachers initiative to improve student achievement by enabling schools to provide health and social services to students and families. Read more here.
In addition to vision and dental, the USC initiative brings in arts and technology!

The principal, Mr. Guzio, the teachers, and even the front desk security guard are so kind and caring with the kids. This school focuses on caring, respect, and sharing." "When my older daughter was her age she was not taught not even a fraction of what the younger one now knows," this parent writes.

Kimberly, a 2001 graduate, writes: "I have nothing but positive things to say about PS 14. The teachers and staff turn PS14 into a home -- I felt that I was in a family and not only a school." She continues: "Every teacher that I had was devoted to giving each and every student a quality learning experience, filled with creativity and expression. Teachers even started their own clubs like the Drama Club and Reading Garden. Going to PS 14 was the best part of my life, and I am proud to say my two younger sisters still attend there."

"My daughter had five wonderful years at PS 14," writes Naomi Lind, a parent. "Every single teacher she had contributed to her education in the most dedicated, loving, warm, caring and professional way. The principal, vice principal, teachers, staff, and PTA all collaborate to make the school the best that it can be. Their dedication to the children's well-being and education is evident throughout the halls and the classrooms. Thank you PS 14 for making every moment enjoyable, for making a difference and for giving my daughter memories to last a lifetime. They will always be cherished."

I have been a PS 36 parent for 4 years now but prior to my daughter attending i have been in and out of this school for the last 15 years with my nephews and nieces.  i have seen this school go from below average back 15 years ago to a HUGE transition with the direction of Mrs. Rivera former principal.  I must say that i am very happy that Ms Maresca who was the Asst. Pricipal was able to become Principal when Mrs Rivera retired to me it was extremely important that the school remained in the hands of someone who already knew the ins and outs of what was going on.  Though many parents (who have complained to me) do not find Ms. Maresca approachable i must say this I felt this way at one point but i addressed my concerns to her in the proper manner and she will respond appropriately but will not hesitate to tell it like it is she's really a no nonsense  individual and isn't shy to tell you the truth and set up straight she's too concerned with educating our kids to waste time on childish behavior from parents.  Unlike the parents that have said that faculty brushes off bad behavior i MUST disagree last year my daughter had a bully that was just so frustrating she didn't want to go to school anyone the first time the children were spoken to and parents addressed as the bullying continued she immediately with the school counselor set up a meeting with my husband and i, the other parent and the children the BULLYING was put to a STOP!!!!  SHE HAS A STRONG NO BULLYING POLICY.  Parents need to know how to approach these situations in a manner they themselves will like to be treated.  
Ms Maresca has truly done much work to make this school an A++ both educationally as well as physically.  It is almost looks like a small suburb school and the saturday classes are a plus.  My friends in the suburbs complain that they don't have that.  I can also say WOO HOO my daughter is getting cursive classes which NO SCHOOL in this are has i was teaching her at home because it was announced on the news that cursive was no longer a must in schools. My husband and i are selling our house to move to the suburbs because of the middle schools and do not want to pay catholic school been there done that with my oldest and trust me not any better but because this school is great i can hold off til she graduates.
So with every PRO there is a CON.  The Parents Association needs MUCH WORK!! we have the same people running it year after year and i don't see any one benefitting but the kindergarten and senior classes as well as themselves.  they are not approachable to new help though they claim they need help and in my opinion MY OPINION we need a huge change.  HUGE there alot of $$ going into PA but not all grade benefit from it leaving me to wonder hmmmmm!!!!!!

"Melissa Salguero, a music teacher from P.S. 48 Joseph R. Drake Elementary School in the Bronx, is the only American among 10 finalists for the Global Teacher Prize," according to The 74.

Grammy Educator Award-nominated PS 48 music teacher Melissa Salguero discussed her techniques for student engagement, development, and resilience in a Chalkbeat report. Salguero says she's unafraid to use unconventional or creative methods, such as teaching sound waves with bananas and asking students for feedback on her lessons, to keep children engaged.

Philip Panaritis, along with PS 48 students and teachers are advocating for a separate monument to be built and additions to the PS 48 curriculum recognizing a slave burial ground at Drake Park, the New York Times reports.
After studying census data, maps, photographs, and wills, students and teachers from PS 48 may have discovered the site of an African slave burial ground in Joseph Rodman Drake Park. Read more here.

PS 48 students discovered a burial ground for Indian and African slaves that the city demolished over a century ago, according to Juan Gonzales at the Daily News. Students are working together to try to identify the unmarked graves in nearby Joseph Rodman Drake park.

Student rappers and dancers won $50,000 for the PS 48's music program. The school was one of 73 nationwide, out of 500 contestants, to win a prize in the contest sponsored by the "Glee gives a note" campaign. Read more: Bronx School Wins $50,000 in Music Contest.

According to a June 30, 2008 New York Sun article, PS 48 "scores is being investigated for allegations that teachers helped students cheat on state tests. Several students who attended P.S. 48 said last week that teachers would examine their answers during official test administration periods and point out mistakes and how to correct them.'They would give you the answers on the state tests,' a graduate of P.S. 48, who is now in seventh grade, said. 'You'd say, 'I need help,' and then they'd tell you what the answer was.' [...] Eleven of 12 P.S. 48 graduates interviewed last week said they were coached during the state tests. They said that teachers would look over their shoulders and instruct them to try again and again until they got answers right. 'They'd be like, 'Is that the right answer?' -- until they make sure it's right,' a sixth-grader said. 'When I was at 48, I never went to class, and I still passed the test," a seventh-grader said. 'If you go to graduation, you pass.' [...] Several staff members at M.S. 201 said they have long suspected cheating went on at P.S. 48. The school feeds its graduates into M.S. 201, and they said students from that school often come unprepared -- despite having high test scores."

Principal John Hughes writes, "It might be a good time to update your review of PS 48, The Best School in the Universe. On Oct. 1, I took 3 kids to see Bruce Springsteen at Shea Stadium, where he read a humorous letter from the stage that I had written him. This was clearly an omen of good things to come. While the rest of the city was going down, our 4th-grade ELA scores jumped 13.6%, making us the 8th-highest performer in the Bronx. Our 3rd-grade math scores went up 30 points and 3rd grade ELA increased by 9. We expect similar results when the 4th-grade mathematics results become available. The Chancellor attended our graduation today and trust me, this is just the beginning."

My daughter will be attending this school this upcoming school year and these comments are from several years ago. I would like to read comments of the current progress from teachers, parents, coordinators.

I used to attend to PS 62 from 1959-1963. I come from blue collar parents with a high scale of values! We moved to Puerto Rico in July 1963. I currently work for schools within the military base with a population of preschool to highschool as a Physical Therapist for children with special needs. I also participate in Shriners Clinic at the VA Hospital twice a year! I'm very proud of my humble beginnings!

PS 69 second graders won a city-wide ferry-naming contest; a ferry will now be named "Urban Journey," WNYC reports.

Actually, the paint club was created by a not-for-profit organization called Publicolor that teamed-up with Alan Cohen and the schools students to facilitate the project.
Principal Alan Cohen received a Time Warner Principals of Excellence Award, given to five public school principals who display "the same leadership skills that are so valued" at Time Warner.
"I want to make sure I have good citizens, good neighbors, and good adults," says Principal Alan Cohen.
"I can't tell you how wonderful the parents are. You call them and they're there," says parent coordinator, Donna Salerno.
"I like this school," says a 3rd grader. "I like the principal. I like the teachers."
Principal Alan Cohen was the recipient of the 2006 Outstanding Administrator of the Year Award, which was awarded for the first time this year.

Parent Elena Vila writes that the school "seemed to be stuck in a rut" because of poor leadership in the past. Now, she says, "due to such an inspirational environment the students strive to do the best that they possibly can... Never did I ever dream that in such a short time this school could accomplish so much. Every year goals are set higher and the students always manage to reach them. "

Principal Alan Cohen received a 2006 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

Parent Coordinator Donna Salerno writes that the school now has a "Chess Club, Lego Robotics Club, Digital Video Club, Breakfast Math Club, Junior and Senior Chorus and NY Road Runners Club just to mention a few."  In addition, "Good Morning America filmed a story about our school and last week we were featured on CBS Sunday Morning News. Scores have steadily improved in both literacy, math and science."

Alexis, a former student, writes: "I would like to say PS 69 is a great school. The staff is friendly and [helpful]. These days a uniform is [required], but when I was there it was your choice. Overall, PS 69 was and still is a wonderful institute for learning."

A former student who is now a 7th-grader at Maritime Academy writes: "Overall, I would say this is a good school, especially because of all the changes that it has made since I was a student there. The school now has a great principal ... There [used to be] plenty of teachers who just didn't care and luckily there are a lot less of those now. I am not sure if this school has undergone all the changes that it was supposedly going to, but I can say that it has come a long way."

"Whatever money is supposed to go to the school, you see it," says Helen Tacome, the PTA president. Administrators, she said, welcome parents, and really care about the kids. "There's an attitude of 'these are my children,'" she says, "not 'these are your children.'"

"I went to this school and it is bad," writes a former student. "I mean if your really smart like I am and like other children I knew you won't let the bad children bother you a lot. But the standards of the school are low. I wouldn't recommend this ... to any parents."

Parent Denise Garcia writes, "My son has been attending PS 69 since 1st grade, and now has just graduated from 4th grade." She adds, "This school is like a small family ...all the children that will attend this school is going to learn while enjoying themselves."

A parent writes that although classes are small at PS 93, they are not challenging. "The teacher has yet to give an exam," this parent writes. "Students do not read out loud in class; any reading is done by the teacher."
Chynna, a student, writes: "[PS 93] is the best school. The teachers are nice and can also be fun, but when it comes down to learning this school is the best."

Principal Donald Mattson writes: "We have a physical education program, music, art, social studies and two science labs. We also have a Literacy Center which contains a wide variety of leveled books in all genres suitable for the wide range of reading ability that exists in grades K-6. This is an extension of our Balanced Literacy philosophy which is the primary model of literacy instruction in all grades. Teachers borrow themed related books for for shared, independent and guided reading. It is also mandated that cluster teachers include literacy in all of their programs. New this year is a Mathematics Resource Center and a Mathematics Staff Developer.

Our 10 self contained special education classes are mainstreamed for physical education, lunch, music, art and assembly programs.

Certainly as in every profession our staff includes people with a wide range and style of ability. Our AUSSIE consultant, literacy coach and math staff developer provide training, insight and assistance to all teachers to provide them with all of the needed resources to become the best teacher that they can.

At the present time we now have several after school programs for both recreation and academic improvement. Also we have developed the P.R.I.D.E. (Promoting, Respect, Intellect and Determination through Education) Academy.

We recognize students for attendance and behavior during our monthy student of the month and attendance award assemblies. Twice a year we have the Principal's Honor Roll assembly (January and June) recognizing students that attained levels 3 and 4 in most subject areas on their report card.

"The teachers are very cooperative with parents," said Parents Association President Jacqueline Rivera, who added that the instructors are committed to ensuring that children get the services they require. She said teachers noticed that one of her children needed more demanding work than PS 93 offered, and referred her to a charter school that was "way more challenging." At the same time, teachers made sure her son received the speech therapy he needed.
"The kids are happy and well-mannered," said parent Joann Malave. "It's welcoming. Everyone looks out for each other."
PS 100 is one of four Bronx schools participating in a new health curriculum sponsored by the New York Junior Tennis League and Emblem Health. Read more here.

My son is a 7th grader now - G&T program, school is great.  School has quality teachers & staff that care and are willing to meet up & discuss concerns w/your child. Teachers use smart boards, students have access to laptops in some classes. Students travel to their classes and are required to carry their book bags around as there are no lockers. The idea of interactive notebooks should be in place to keep relevant notes available to all students instead of a bunch of handouts that typically get misplaced in multiple folders. Discipline is taken care of by the AP, the dean and rarely have heard anything serious to be concerned about.  Curriculum is challenging but appropriate. Their communication is very good and use apps for easier and fast communication. There is opportunity for extracurricular activities after school. Supposedly they have a track team that my son was interested in joining last year but never heard anything about it. School puts on an incredible musical theater show in May where interested students have the opportunity to audition, rehearse and perform. I have noticed that the G&T program is not a true G&T program because some students that should be in G&T are placed in the regular school while others that do not belong in G&T are in the G&T.
Pros: communication, curriculum, arts, music, and drama, discipline, uniform, after school programs: chess, debate, band practice, etc, parent breakfast with the principal
Cons: no lockers, limited sports team besides basketball, early lunch for 6th graders (10:30am).

hi no offense but this school's gifted and talented program helped me get into a specialized highschool ( BxSci ) with 8 highschool credits already fulfilled and the teachers were for the large majority.. so great and enthusiastic and supportive. if you're wondering about what school to send your kid to i strongly encourage you to apply for their g&t program it makes a world of difference in NY

I'm currently a seventh grader at M.S. 101. I can proudly say I am very excited to be in this school. I'm in one of the gifted classes, and all the teachers are really nice. The teachers can be strict, but that means everyone will be well behaved. It offers many clubs and after-school activities and all the rooms have air conditioning. The school is great and I would recommend it!

I am an eigth grader at the moment in ms 101. obviously, the school has undergone so many changes in the past two years. just to say, the principal is doing an amazing job involving the school in many artnerships and sticking to a stricter more acedemical side. now, we have a stricter uniform policy but i believe that it is better to wear uniform rather than to struggle to find the perfect outfit everyday and clean clthes and all differently just to not getvpicked on. sorry for my spelling errors. however, there are so many programs and cluns going on that i was not aware, it is a good yet bad thig. the school is very disorganized however, a new guidance counselor has been hired yet i've never really noticed her. our previous guidance counselor was always around when you needed it. that is another thing. this school seems like you cant do anthing about the issue. the principal is always occupied so if you have a complaint all the teachers and staff will appoint you to him. but he wuld never have time to adress the matter. i think that s  big flaw. over all the disorgnization and not knowing of whats going on(not to mention we got our specialized high school test tickets last minute) its a good school. the education system alone is amazing. however, i will say, if you are not in gifted and talented, please stay focused because there is a fine line between those barriers. although this sounds wrong, its the truth, i've noticed g and t is more mature and responsible than the other students. you can still do amzing in the other classes but in g and t, you actually have more oppurtunites when it cmes to taing regen ts. you get more done. the other classes are still incredibly smart but if you want to accomplish or challenge yourself more, g and t is the way to go! i wish all fifth graders good luck. ad again, sorry for all errors in spelling and conventions.

Just to start off, 101 is an amazing school. The classes are very rigorous especially for gifted and talented students such as my self. We are offered a variety of regents such as earth science, integrated algebra, English language arts, and Spanish proficiency. The atmosphere of the school is warm and welcoming. The teachers are all amazing. They care about our present academics and our future. In addition to their awesomeness, the teachers make learning fun. They are all strict and get the job done, you will definitely learn here. In addition to our academics we have an immense amount of extra curricular activities including boys and girls basketball, dance, art, music, band, drama, yearbook, history club, track, and many test preps if needed. 23 of our graduating students including my self got into specialized highschools. 101 has a spectacular music program and the music teacher is the best teacher there. She has done many things for her students and her life is really devoted to us. We've performed in all the boroughs except for Staten Island and she has recently fundraised 3000 dollars for the program. Yes, one math teacher gets criticized a lot but she is an amazing teacher. She expects highly of her students and only wishes the best for them. She may seem intimidating and very strict but over all you may not like her but you would be lucky to get her. Our new principal Mr. Rosoff has really turned the school for the best and knows everyone by name. He is really doing a fantastic job. 101 has rally prepared me for highschool, college, and the future with its amazing staff and academics. I will really be sad to leave such an amazing school this year.

Yes, as explained above, one of the teachers is a bit more criticized than most. All the statements made above are true, but with luck, you may receive the other math teacher. This teacher is known to be loud and last year she broke glass on a door by slamming it too hard. I'm not trying to scare people off, but although this teacher has had over a decade of experience as a teacher, her skills both sociably and as a teacher can be a bit fine-tuned.

I have a current eighth grader attending MS 101. Mr. Rosoff took leadership last December and has created a warm and welcoming environment. My daughter is excelling academically and socially. She attends weekly test preparation for the Specialized High School examination, as well as the Social Studies club. She is enthusiastic about showing school spirit by attending all at-home basketball games, volunteering whenever possible, and engaging in all available activities. 



Mr. Rosoff welcomes parents to monthly breakfasts in which information is disseminated, personal questions are answered, and connections are made with parents. He personally answers all email within an hour of receipt, which, I find amazing. Mr. Rosoff's leadership style is endearing, positive, and attentive. The open door policy has me visiting the school more than I ever have in the past. 



I will definitely send my younger son to MS 101 next year!

This school absolutely sucks now it used to be at the top of its game back in 2010 but it took a sharp nosedive many of the great teachers have left and the school just about lets anyone join. I don't recommend this school as an eight grader who will be leaving shortly i encourage that all students use this school as a last resort.

I am  attending M.S. 101 and am currently in the eighth grade. I believe that this school has tremendously gone downhill since I first arrived. I remember entering the school eager to be apart of the Gifted and Talented program. Now, the program has been completely removed and there is no longer a rigorous program. The teachers here at M.S 101 barely care about your academic future. In my opinion, they do not provide the students with a helpful and understanding ambiance. There are very few clubs present in this school which is another downside. I am sorry to say that I am counting down the days until I graduate from this school.

I completely disagree with your opinion. I am also an eighth grader @ 101 and the classes, especially the earth science and algebra classes can't get much harder. Also, most, if not all the teachers at M.S. 101 do care for not only us, but for our future as well. As for extracurricular, we have dance, chess, chorus, boy's basketball, girl's basketball, debate, newsletter, and play rehearsal (drama).

Ms.101 is a great school. If you are considering this school, I recommend it. Our school is small but friendly. Almost everyone knows everyone, and if you don't know anyone, you can try out for after school programs, Dance team, Cheerleading, Basketball (Boys and Girls) . I recommend this school because not only will you find many clubs or programs that interest you, you also have a lot of people backing you up. 

If you are wondering about teachers, they are tough but fair. They will push you to do your best, but if they didn't you wouldn't get anywhere. As for the Principals (3 of them), They are all nice and welcoming. I'm not going to lie, they are strict when it comes to uniform and class work, but they only mean best, and if you need someone to talk to, they are welcoming and always behind you. 

This is my last year in Ms.101 and I love my teachers and my classes. I'll miss everyone, but I'm ready to move foward in my life and my school is very supporting of that. Many students may complain about the work, or the teachers, but I think in the end, almost everyone will miss our small school, and funny, down to earth teachers. If you're a parent or a student, I think this school is a wonderful. Honestly, if I had to do this again and pick a middle school; I wouldn't hesitate to pick Ms.101 :) I hope this helps anyone having doubts or just wanting an actual student's point of view.

I'm in the graduating class of 2012 and M.S.101 is the BEST. Teachers come to work everyday willing and fully prepared to enlighten students, the school maintains a comfortable and neat order, and very rarely will a fight occur. (It'd probably be a "she said, he said".) Class sizes vary depending on whether you are or are not in the Gifted and Talented program. We share the school with two others but it feels as the the entire school is ours considering we are allowed on the floors for the other schools. We have a large library run by a previous 6th grade social studies teacher who expands the array of books available each month. Also, the gym (on the first floor,) is very large. There are two gym teachers, both very dedicated and always making gym entertaining and active even for those who aren't. (Believe I was one and I ended up loving gym.) I took Spanish for three years,( this is my third) and I know a majority of the language due to the teacher and her goals set. When days are warm, gym is held outside and if requested, so is class, under s tree. There are AC's in each room, which work, and there are computer (three) in each room assisted by one of the two laptop carts that travel 'round from class to class when desired. S.S. Teachers show films ad actual evidence from scenes and war fronts very often. And math teachers aid students who need help. There is extended moning for students who want to catch up after missing a day, or do not fully understand the work. Many teachers take time out if their busy schedules and stay after school, (as long as it takes,) until the child understands. The principal, (Mrs. Hewitt, is a very joyous spirit, conducting weekly check ups on teachers and students to maintain order. There is so much more, so many other good things, and you'd be crazy not to send your child here. It's an amazing school with a calm and gentle atmosphere.

PS 107 is on the state education department’s list of failing schools but it doesn’t qualify for the city’s renewal program, which gives schools additional support. Read more here.
Dental health clinics will open in four schools in the Bronx next year, including Mott Hall Community School: NYC Schools to offer oral health-care clinics.

P.S. 107 is a participant in the Wellness in the Schools
Cook for Kids program, which replaces the traditional cafeteria menu with
a healthy menu based on scratch cooking and fresh ingredients. WITS
places a trained culinary profession in the school cafeteria to prepare fresh
meals from scratch, engage students, and educate families about the importance
of eating whole, unprocessed foods through interactive cooking demonstrations
called WITS Labs. You can find out more about programming from Wellness in the
Schools and see a list of participating schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org

P.S. 107 is on a list of schools that the DOE may close. The schools were on the state's persistently lowest achieving list last spring and have low tests scores, with fewer than 30% of the students reading at grade level. Additionally all but one received a "D" or an "F" on the city progress reports. After last year's union lawsuit prevented the city from closing 19 schools, a judge ruled that the city needs to communicate better with the schools' communities. This year officials are also considering closing the 19 schools identified last year. Education officials will also consider alternatives to closing the schools, including removing the principals and changing staff. Check this link in the Daily News.
According to a July 7, 2008 New York Daily News article, the school will recieve a playground by September 2008.
PS 107 is "an undeveloped school with a number of proficient features," according to the New York City Department of Education's quality review report.
One visitor notes, "Despite the negative events that sometimes occur in the neighborhood, the school provides a safe and clean evironment for the kids."

I went to this school in the mid-70s, Kindergarten through 5th grade and have some fond memories of the school and staff. However, I can say that I was one of the kids who slipped through the BOE 'cracks' as at that time they did not recognize a neglect case. It was such a shame and still makes me sad to think of what I lost out on as a child. I left that school during the 6th grade year ('79 or '80?)  and transferred to two other schools in the area and never completed any grade past 6th. The BOE must have lost track of me, which was my neglectful mothers intent at the time. I truly hope things have changed in regards to the BOE handling these types of cases.

An Assemblywoman in the Bronx is proposing that city schools should be required to offer Halal lunch options that meet Muslim dietary guidelines. According to the Bronx Times, this new rule would help students at schools like PS 119 that have growing Muslim populations. Read more here.

I went to school here over 3 years ago. 
What happened?

P.S. 119 undoubtedly has a great staff but the students range from either very intelligent or driven to extremely in need of attention. They can't adequately give challenges to students who are ahead of their peers (I've never actually done my homework at home in P.S. 119. I'd just finish it at school after my classwork was done) My teachers left a great impression on me and my siblings (all of us attended P.S. 119) but if your a bit ahead in classes, then you'll be bored. A lot of my former classmates are attending Bronx Science now along with me so there's a good chance that you'll be old students again.

PS 119 has had overcrowding problems for two decades. Now parents fear even more overcrowding problems will follow in the wake of a new middle school in the neighborhood. Read more from the Daily News and also an editorial on the overcrowding issues from Juan Gonzalez.

A social worker at JHS 123 James M. Kieran, Margaret Prisinzano, goes above and beyond to support her students conducting financial-literacy workshops for underprivileged families, providing therapy for homeless kids, helping parents learn English, and even driving to Virginia this past spring to pick up donated formal wear for her students to wear to their eighth-grade graduation and prom, the Daily News reports.

JHS 123 James M. Kieran is one of 27 New York City schools on the 2015-2016 list of schools considered to be "persistently dangerous" by the state Department of Education, based on the number of disruptive or violent incidents. Read more here.

Irina Gonzalez, a middle school social studies teacher at J.H.S. 123 James M. Kieran was honored in a ceremony at Gracie Mansion and presented with a Big Apple Award. Read more here.

An Oct. 3, 2004 Daily News article profiled Yankee icon Ruben Sierra's donations of "dozens of basketballs, baseballs, footballs and other athletic equipment... His decision to help P.S. 130 came after he was shown a letter, written by Yolende Van Putten, the school's program director, detailing the poor state of the school's athletic facilities." The article also mentioned his visit to the school. "On Thursday, Sierra got to see the tangible benefits of his support. He opened boxes of new equipment, signed autographs on donated baseballs and passed out Ruben Sierra Yankee wristbands. 'As far as Ruben is concerned, he has adopted P.S. 130,' declared Spalding Community Relations Director Ray Negron.

The staff at P.S. 130 couldn't have been more pleased. 'All of the players are very motivating to our kids,' said school principle Danny Garcia. 'The fact that Ruben's taking an interest will make a significant difference.'" (2004)

"The best thing about this school, I have to say, is Mr. Garcia," said a mother active in the Parents' Association. "He's a great person. If there's anything you need, anything that he can help you with, he really tries his best." (2002)

IS 131 is a terrible school at best. The students have no respect for teachers or administration, there are multiple fights every day, and children are constantly wandering the halls cutting class. Bullying is a very prevalent thing at this school despite all of the anti-bullying posters hanging around the building. Students frequently use inappropriate language in class and in the halls, disrupt class, come to class unprepared, and feel that they can do whatever they want whenever they want. 131's motto of being "prepared, punctual, and polite" is an empty alliteration as most students are never prepared or polite. However, they do show up to class on time, for the most part, unless they are part of the "Hallwalkers." The school has no Dean, and no form of consequences for student misbehavior other than calling their parents.

The principal is well aware of the disciplinary problems at the school but chooses to blame teachers for poor classroom management. The principal has little control over the students so she exerts her power over the teachers and other staff in abusive and bullying ways. Some teachers are favored while others are bullied with no rhyme or reason as to why. The easiest way to survive at 131 and maintain your sanity (and job) is to remain under the radar. It is a toxic environment was extremely low morale.

Dear Soapbox Sarah;
I am disgusted by the comments you make here.  Your animosity against the school is very unprofessional.  I am a Parent Association Executive Board member who is at the school from 8:00am to 5:30pm everyday volunteeting.  I have yet to see or hear about some of the accusations you make here.  Tell me something!;  which institution have you worked on that doesn't have one or two bad apples?  When you do find it, please let me know because I want to go work for them.  Respect is something that is given to others in order to be received back and Authority is taught in order to obtain control of your work environment.  In a Title I school we should expect to find students that are often unprepared.  It is our responsibilities as teachers, administrators & Parents Associations to find help and/or provide for these students.  When as a teacher, you don't make it your business to find out why these children are not prepared, then that only says one thing to me & that is; that you are just an employee & not a teacher.  In many cases, families may not have the means to provide their children with the supplies, uniforms, etc.  The school's Parent Association is willing to help.  The Principal is a very well respected individual by students, parents and all.  If she blames a teacher for lack of discipline in their classrooms is because she has the necessary proof to back her decisions.  No discipline in the classrooms is due to lack of teachers authority, which translate to no instructional time for our children.  So,  we that said; I am personally grateful  that our Principal chooses instruction over instructors that are obviously only looking at the clock to go out to eat or to go home.

I worked at this school as a substitute teacher and was treated with such respect! Mr. Nevers (AP) was the greatest host and made me and the other substitutes feel like we were part of the team! He spent 15-20 minutes giving us a tour and placing us in classes that we were qualified to teach. I believe he was also trying to place us in the least stressful situations. I think he understood and CARED that we were coming in to unfamiliar surroundings and didn't want us to be overwhelmed trying to balance behavior issues, routines, schedules and teaching. It was a smart move on his part because the substitutes will want to keep coming back which provides the students consistency & saves him the trouble of trying to find coverage everytime a teacher is out as well as the trouble of always having to show substitutes around in the morning. I know a lot of principals or assistant principals don't even handle placing the subs. They allow the secretaries to place them. It makes no sense. The only bad thing was that the teacher did not leave the plans in the room or the office. But Mr. Nevers called her to email plans and she sent them. It got to me a little late in the morning but it ended up being a great day at that school. I did notice that a lot of the kids had filthy mouths (even as young as 1st grade) and liked to play fight a lot! There were some problems with fighting in the classroom across the hall from me. However, there are cameras everywhere in the building so a kid threatens to hit you tell them to meet you in the hall and let the video tell the story! I had a special education class 12:1. They all liked to bicker and play fight while on line but they were really wonderful kids! I would go back again!

P.S. 140 is a participant in the Wellness in the Schools Cook for
Kids program, which replaces the traditional cafeteria menu with a healthy
menu based on scratch cooking and fresh ingredients. WITS places a
trained culinary profession in the school cafeteria to prepare fresh meals from
scratch, engage students, and educate families about the importance of eating
whole, unprocessed foods through interactive cooking demonstrations called WITS
Labs. You can find out more about programming from Wellness in the Schools and
see a list of participating schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org

A PS 146 teacher told Insideschools, "Every two weeks we evaluate each student's reading and adjust their books to give them variety. "
"It's better here," said a 3rd grade parent. "Everything has changed."

"It's been challenging convincing parents that they're welcome here," said Yvette Johnson, parent coordinator. "There are financially challenged parents, and their top priority is not P.A. meetings. They're just trying to get money for rent and meals. But I enjoy them. They make me feel good that I came to work here."

"I like that children really need you," said a 2nd grade teacher. "I don't agree with the [city-mandated] balanced literacy program. I think they should bring the basic [basal] reading textbooks back."

"Teaching is a passion for me," said a 4th grade teacher. "I've been here 16 years. I would like to see more participation from the community and more economic, social and political stability for people who live in the area."
"The parents are very supportive," said a 1st grade teacher. "People think that because of their socio-economic backgrounds they wouldn't be, but I've seen the opposite."
"The kids are challenging," said a 1st grade teacher. "They have lots of family problems. There are lots of families where kids have no role models."
"I like seeing them learn to read and start writing in kindergarten," said a kindergarten teacher. "For homework, they bring questions home and their parents help them write the answers."
"They have to be able to recognize 10 words at the end of the year," said a kindergarten teacher.

I came across this website only because CS 152 so positively impacted me as a student decades ago that I had to check on it's current status.  Judging by the above review, things seem to only have gotten better.  I spent nearly a decade working as a counselor at various schools in the Bronx and never found another that could hold a candle to CS 152.  At this school, children actually learn.  The faculty is capable and caring and the school environment is conducive to learning.  Those are rare qualities to find in Bronx schools these days.

There are tons of Hispanics in 152 and sometimes they are really racial. I'm a south Asian so I couldn't really find anyone to interact with. I was always being judged because I wasn't part of the Hispanic community which sucked. I was always the kid that was picked last when it came to partners and teaming up with someone. But I did have good time for the 2 years that I have been there. It had been a thrill. Ms. Ortega and Ms. Suarez were amazing and so was Ms.Goodman.
