Thank you "Lizzy" for your perspective. It is rather informative, yet also somewhat misleading. A school is as strong as its people who work in it and support its vitality and needed improvement. The school community has the capacity to either improve or bring a school down. First of all, sometimes change is good. Some people left the school this last school year (the percentage was actually smaller than described- 6 out of 70) for various reasons, which happens each year in many schools. People seek schools closer due to moving, people get promoted, or fail to see things from different viewpoints. You're right, communication in the school can be better. But it is important to remember that communication works both ways. While communication (primarily gossip, which is hard to control outside of the school) has been previously posed as "the issue" and the scapegoat for the true issue-the need for significant progress with respect to student achievement, it is important to note that the school has made progress in different ways and will continue to improve if there is a UNITED front and a decreased number of professionals putting the school down, rather than improving it. It is a fact (data doesn't lie)that the school has made gains as it relates to achievement in ELA & Math this school year with many English Language Learners testing out on the NYESLAT and scoring level 3 and 4 on state tests. Let's focus on highlighting what should change and how to fix the perceived problem(s), but what the school does well. Every school has its problems. No school is perfect, and people will inevitably always find something to gripe or complain about. Rather than offering a diatribe please answer this question for the community: What specific, viable solutions do you recommend for improving the perceived "disfunctions" of the administration and "issues"?  Let's be a part of the solution, not the problem.

THE SCHOOL IS NO LONGER WHAT IT USED TO BE. ALONG WITH ADMINISTRATION CHANGES AT THE TOP, POLITICS HAVE TAKEN OVER FROM WHAT ONCE UPON A TIME USED TO BE AN ENERGETIC, WARM AND TRULY CARING STUDENT / TEACHER ENVIRONMENT. THE SCHOOL HAS HAD ALOT OF HIDDEN SCANDALS , EVERYTHING FROM  P.T.A  CORRUPTION , EMPLOYEE HARRASMENT TO LACK OF PROPER SECURITY. COMMUNICATION IS OFTEN LOST DUE TO VARIOUS ADMINISTRATIVE DISFUNCTIONS. STUDENTS AND PARENTS ALIKE SENSE AND OFTEN SEE THESE DISFUNCTIONS AS THE ISSUE CAN BE CLEARLY SEEN IN THE FRUSTRATION OF THE TEACHERS AND SUPPORT STAFF'S FACES AND THE LARGE EMPLOYEE TURN OVERS AT THE END OF EVERY YEAR. THE SCHOOL NEEDS TRUE LEADERSHIP WHICH IT LACKS, AND IT NEEDS TO TAKE OUT THE "I" IN TEAM BECAUSE AS OF THE LAST 2 YEARS ADMINISTRATION HAS BEEN ALLOWING ITSELF AND EVERYONE ELSE TO SPELL IT WRONG......................GET YOUR ACTS TOGETHER.

Schools in this program will receive $3.5 million in direct funding to help ensure that students graduate with clear college and career plans by 2018.
is this school good

Boxing author John E. Oden was honored at a school fundraiser.  Oden was instrumental in creating a boxing program at Archimedes. A New York Times article about the program says a semester of boxing instruction is offered to sixth graders as a credit-bearing physical education class. In addition, there is a non-credit afterschool boxing program open to all grades.
See videos of high tech classrooms and the robotics lab in an article in Tech & Learning.
The Scholastic blog heaps praise on principal, Miriam Lazar and links a video profile of the school, including a look inside the robotics department.

My granddaughter attended this school and graduate she did so well she got into a prestigious Manhattan High School The principal is very helpful and cares a lot for the students and staff He runs a well oiled machine. He makes sure the kids are learning and offer achievements and rewards to them. So happy she choose this school it was a pleasure going to the plays that were well done.

When I read that the principal punished a faculty member for serving in our Military Reserves, I was shocked. As a retired principal and National Guard officer I can only say that my military service was an asset to our country and to the students in which I served.   This principle must understand that her students are looking to her to set the example for supporting all aspects of the educational process. Her actions reflected poorly upon her judgment and was a poor example for her students.

Urban Institute of Mathematics has been selected to participate in the Department of Education's Community Schools initiative, aimed at boosting attendance and achievement by bringing in community partners to provide support for students and families. Urban Institute of Mathematics's partner is East Side House. Read more about the program here and see the full list of schools, their community partners and their proposed services here.
Dental health clinics will open in four schools in the Bronx next year, including Urban Institute of Mathematics: NYC Schools to offer oral health-care clinics.

After being identified by the DOE as one of 29 middle schools that are under-performing in literacy, UIM has changed the way it teaches English. 6th and 7th graders are now required to take an extra English class, and all teachers are now expected to address literacy in their classrooms. Read more here.

I am a current UIM senior this school is great everyone knows everyone, some of the teachers are cool. It's not as hard as people think it would be. Yes we do wear uniform it's pretty strict but you get use to it after a while. The students are nice there necessarily don't have any cliques everyone talks to everyone no matter if they are in 6th 7th or 8th. The teachers do encourage to always try your best and they will offer to let you stay if help is needed. We rarely interact with the two other schools, only during certain gym classes, in the morning or while transferring to a class on the first floor. You can always have a good laugh with Ms. Joynt our principal, Mr. Martin our vice principal, Mr. Simman our dean, and Ms. Andino our parent coordinator. Our guidance Ms. Paraguini is very helpful with the high school process whether if you are looking for a private school, a specialized high school, a performing arts school, our just one of New Yorks many public schools. I'm really going to miss it here i made a lot of new friends and made so many memories we're like one big family. If you are looking to send your son/daughter here it'll be one of the best decisions you'll make for them. Class Of 2013 woohoo! :)

Some teachers are great, others not - just like any school.  Bullying still exists in the school, although they try to deal with it.  Administration does not support each grade equally.  The students and parents are very aware of this fact even though administration denies it.  The dean is also inept.  School bragged about lots of afterschool activities when we started, but hardly has any now.

I totally disagree with both comments below. I pulled my child from a private catholic school to put them here. I would highly recommend this school

PROS: ...

I can go on forever. This school WANTS to be great, but the majority of the children are stopping them. This school is anything but united. Kids smack each other around, don't know their entire graduating class, and have total disrespect for each other. The Urban Institute of Mathematics used to have a college-bound theme. The children wore polos with their college graduation year sewn on. This idea has been phased out. I guess the administration realized they weren't dishing out college-bound children. I expect this from any public school in a bad area; but UIM puts itself on a pedestal. This school promises so much and fails to deliver.

I can't agree more with the other poster. This is a horrible school. "Scholars" aren't graduating on time! The few kids who actually DO their work get criticized by slackers. After the hype dies down, the school will deteriorate. It's a vicious cycle. Will it ever end?

The Hunts Point School is on a list of 50 schools that will participate in the DOE's Bronx Plan, which will boost salaries in hard-to-staff positions and "give teachers formal decision-making power in their schools" according to Chalkbeat.
The Hunts Point School has made "demonstrable improvement," even though it is still struggling, the New York State Education Department said, according to Chalkbeat.

In 2016 Hunts Point's statewide test scores fell in both math and English, the New York Times reports. The school already had low test scores, but in 2016 just 6 percent of students were proficient in English while only 4 percent were at grade level in math.
The Hunts Point School has been removed from the State Education Department's list of struggling schools and no longer faces possible receivership. Politico New York reports.

I recently became involved with a new circus class offered after school at MS424. Before the first class, I was warned about the metal detectors as though the presence of metal detectors at the school reflects directly on the behavior of the students who currently go there.  While I understand the significant difficulties that this school faces, the staff that I have met have been so helpful in getting us acclimated to the school, and the students I have the pleasure of working with are curious, intelligent, creative and very talented. Such behavior that have occurred come from lack of confidence in themselves and lack of patience and focus due to enthusiasm and energy. If anything, some of them strike me as more mature and self-possessed than other children their age. I have also worked for 6 years at a circus program in the neighborhood attended by students and alumni of MS424, and they are some of my most dedicated, creative and talented students. I want to let people know that amidst all the challenges the school and these young people face, there are some really wonderful students and staff at MS424.

I am a parent of a 6th grade scholar, and  this school is AWESOME! The  Soundview Academy teachers believed in my son, and that he  could excel. So now,  after years of  struggling academically through grade school,  my son believes he can excel!  The educational expectations are high, and the administration/teachers/staff  have the expertise, energy   and academic support services to turn students into scholars.    This strength based school begins by looking at  the glass as half full, and then works to fill the glass all the way to the top. All of the pieces work collectively (the administration, the teachers, the professional staff, & the support services) to make this school wonderful, and as a parent, I can't ask for more than that!

My name is Patricia Blackwell,
My son was one of the first 6 graders entering Soundview.
We meet Mr. Frack before school opened. We were able to listen to what he
expected from the children and us as parents. This was a new school and I knew
it was going to take time to mold it. Every year got better, and better. Mr.
Frack tried his best to pick teachers who were excited to teach and who wanted
to do their job and educate our children no matter what type of background they
came from, or nationality. He had his hand in every aspect of the school from
teachers, after school programs, art programs, sports. He wanted the school to
be well rounded in every way.


My child entered this school as a shy child, and very quite.
The mentor program is the best I have ever seen. They instilled in him to
strive for higher grades, to express himself, and to be out going. They turned
my son into a young man. When he left Sound view he was on honor roll. Also, he
is looking forward to go to college. They deal with our children on an
educational level, and on a personal level.


My child was very safe at this school. They do not tolerate
fighting, or bullying.


This school took the student on trips to colleges, theaters,
etc.


Your child will look at this school as a second home. I hope
this will help you on making the best decision for your child. Soundview is the
best school to send your child.

As an experienced substitute teacher in NYC public schools, I must say that Soundview Academy stands out as a school that demonstrates cohesiveness, structure, and a strong supportive administrative team. Everyone has been approachable and informative.  From my first day at Soundview, teachers and administrators have welcomed me into their team and have served as guide and support, extending from being prepared to assisting with classroom management. Each day that I have substituted, there has been a thorough lesson plan ready for me.  This is admirable on the behalf of the teachers at Soundview because it displays not only professionalism but a care for their scholars. Mr. Frackelton (The Principal), is a great Team Leader who leads by example and shows commitment; by walking the hallways along with the scholars while inquiring about how they are doing and building an administrative team that is strong.  It is an honor for me to be of service at Soundview Academy.

Mr. Savery

I am a student here, and i can say it was a bad school but now it changed a whole lot! If you're child is concerned and pays attention to the classes, then this is the school for them. Dress code is highly recommended. The down side is that we get out too late (3:45 p.m).

Hi Kathy,

Thanks for your post.  Yes, our first years were rockier but Rome is not built in a day.  We are now one of the strongest middle schools in the area and the only Dual Language program in the entire district.

You forgot to tell them, however, that you have earlier days to compensate for the long days. With the new demands on you guys from the Common Core Learning Standards you'll be glad, however, we pushed you as much as we did.  You'll thank us when you get to high school!

comment:
I think people should be MORE concerned with which schools are NOT on this list.  Yeah, Soundview Academy is "persistently" dangerous, but they report EVERYTHING and REASON kids get in trouble.  They follow that CHancellor Code of Conduct book my kid got at the beginning of the school year.  

Sometimes I sit and wonder what the "GOOD" schools are NOT reporting, what are they hiding?

I can guarantee that I can sit into any one of my child's classrooms and see what she is learning.  Yeah its a school within a school and the staff is young but they are all easily accessible. if i have a questions it gets answered.  They hammerdown on bullying especially cyberbullying.  

What zoned school do you know has WELL-BEHAVED kids?  Give me that list, Im sure there is NONE!  This school is doing GREAT with the cards they are dealt!

Thanks for the reply.  When we came into the community we did not accept the prevailing wisdom that bullying is normal.  We went strictly by the Chancellor's Regulations and we reported what took place, followed by strong interventions and follow up.  Now we have one of the safest middle schools in the area and a grade of a B.  As I say, safety trumps everything.  So, things are not always as simple as they may appear.  Come up and see the school anytime to see for yourself how serious we are about our scholars' safety and the school environment.

Yes, When I dropped my son off at school every morning most of the teachers are outside watching the students. They even go to the park and make sure everyone is in the school on time. The security guards goes to the park as well. Nothing is 100% safe, but they try very hard. Whatever they are doing it is working!!!!!!!!!!!

Before a new school was created in IS 131,also known as Albert Einstein, the school as a whole was not bad.  Although it had a few problems, it was never on a list of worst schools...but now we have this so called new academy, Soundview Academy for Culture &..inside the IS 131 school with their own principal & what is this we are hearing...one of the worst schools.  Its new, how did that happen!  Stop the experimenting with our children...the goal was to improve a school, not separate & marked unsafe.  Children, please talk to yr parents they need to know eveyrthing in order to protect you.  Talk to any adult until one does listen.  Your safety is priority.

You should go and check out the school before you talk about something you don't know. There are going to be changes in all schools. JHS 22 is on a list of 50 schools that will participate in the DOE's Bronx Plan, which will boost salaries in hard-to-staff positions and "give teachers formal decision-making power in their schools" according to Chalkbeat.

JHS 22 is still waiting to find out whether they have made enough progress to be taken off of the state's Persistently Struggling Schools list, or if it will be taken over by a state-appointed receiver. Schoolbook reports.

New York City's Department of Design and Construction runs a summer camp at MS 22 that teaches basic architectural and engineering concepts. The department also works with the school during the academic year, Schoolbook reports.
MS 22 focused on increasing parent involvement during the 2015-2016 school year. Read or listen to the Schoolbook report here.

In an effort to improve academic performance, MS 22 introduced a new curriculum based on the "growth mindset" concept developed by Stanford psychologist Carol Dweck, which aims to help students take more control over their learning. Read more here.
State Education Commissioner MaryEllen Elia visited JHS 22 to see changes the school is making to get off the "persistently struggling schools" list, reports WNYC's Schoolbook.

Despite pressure to improve test scores, JHS resists "test prep". Principal Edgar Lin told WNYC, "if we prepare kids only to make sense of the test, we're not doing our jobs." Listen to the Schoolbook report here.
JHS 22 has been removed from the State Education Department's list of struggling schools and no longer faces possible receivership at the end of the 2015-2016 school year. Politico New York reports.
JHS 22 is one of three schools at risk of being handed over to an independent receiver by the end of the year if test scores and graduation rates don't improve. Read more here.
MS 22 is focusing on improving students' vocabulary to boost test scores. Read about the initiative here.
As a school in the city's Renewal program, MS 22 receives additional support but must improve to avoid closure. Listen to the WNYC story abut MS 22 here.
JHS 22 principal Edgar Lin, whose school has been targeted for improvement, testified at the Renewal hearing that the new supports were working for his school. Read more here.

MS 22 Students planted yellow and purple flowers in the tree beds along E. 167th Street in Morrisania, with help from their math teacher to celebrate themselves and host a party for the kids and the neighborhood. Read more here.
The 7th-grade dean at JHS 22 Jordan L. Mott, a Chabad Hasid, has improved discipline and behavior without losing favor with students. Read more here.
JHS 22 is one of 27 programs this year to be chosen as a "showcase school," where teachers, parents, superintendents and principals will tour and share best practices. Read more here.
Principal Lin praises District 9's superintendent Leticia Rodriguez-Rosario for her openness and initiative in helping administrators and parents boost up the troubled district. Read more here.

Sixty-two NYC schools could be taken over by outside groups within two years, and seven of those even sooner. JHS 22 has been designated “Persistently struggling,” and now has a one-year deadline. Read more here.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,” by DiBlasio. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.

"The comment from 12/12/08 is right on the mark. NONE of the founding teachers of the French program, PAC, VIP remain at the school. New teachers were not provided with mentors from the DOE, were not evaluated regularly, and were not supported with a cohesive curriculum. Most quit out of frustration, and the couple of them that got fired did not deserve it. I heard from current teachers that the teachers' union has been watching that school like a hawk this year because of what went down last year and the year before. The former principal ran the school on favoritism and fear. I hope, for the sakes of the children and my former colleagues still there, that the current administration can undo the damage that has been done at that place. The irony is that the majority of the founding teachers of those programs landed jobs at better-performing public and charter schools (even the ones that were fired), and some are moving into/training for leadership positions now."

According to a February 2008, New York Times article, Principal Shimon Waronker, who is "a member of the Chabad-Lubavitch sect of Hasidic Judaism with a beard, a black hat and a velvet yarmulke," has surpassed the culture shock of his Black and Hispanic students and their parents by transforming a chaotic, dangerous school, into a safe place with good teaching.

"I applaud the efforts of Shimon Waronker," writes an insideschools.org user. "The teachers that are resistant to the changes are most likely those that are the root of the educational problem. Even in Los Angeles it is astounding how many of our children go through a metal detector each day. I grew up in the Bronx and even 35 + years ago these schools were beginning to fail. Give this man a chance - it's the only hope we have!"
"I like the school, because I thought the 8th graders would be mean, but they weren't. Everyone gets along," said one 5th grader.

A student complains that water pressure in the bathrooms is low and sometimes there is no soap. In addition, some textbooks have scribbling in them. However, this student said the atmosphere has improved and the tone is "much stricter."

"It's a great place to work," said math teacher, Kevin Allard, who arrived at the school in February 2006. "You can actually get in to see the principal. At other schools, you have to go through a chain of command, but not here, if you want something, you just ask. I haven't asked for anything that I haven't received,"
A student said the school is mostly "fun" but added that there are fights among students "like once a week... and I would like that to change."

"In 5th grade I was scared and terrified," recalls an 8th grader. "There were a lot of gangs. People were smoking and drinking in the bathrooms. There wasn't a dress code, so people would wear pjs and short skirts to school. Now it's way better. Classes are more focused and calm."
"This is a great campus," said Principal Nick Marinacci of Bronx Writing Academy, which shares the building. "There's no 'this is mine. This is yours.'"
CIS 22 has been added to the state's list of Schools Under Registration Review because of poor performance on the state math exam.

Principal Shimon Waronker received a 2007 Cahn fellowship, a 16-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize and develop outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor other principals, while continuing to serve as principal at their schools.

John Chew, a teacher at a CIS 22 feeder school, writes to say that he has been impressed with Principal Shimon Waronker, who has created an honors academy and is committed to giving teachers more autonomy. "CIS 22 has many improvements to make, but it seems to me that Mr. Waronker is here to stay and is committed to not only turning 22 around, but to making it into an amazing middle school. and I for one think he can do it," Chew writes.

A student writes that the halls are more orderly than they used to be at CIS 22, but still "teachers can't control the kids" and the school is weak academically. "This year they started a program called Progressive Academy for Change which took all the good kids, leaving the bad ones in regular 22. Even though PAC is for honors, it still teaches the regular curriculum."

"The moral of the teachers,students and parents is at an all time low since the new principal Mr Waronker started," writes a parent. "He has suspended students for yawning and slouching in their seats. He has made crazy rules like the school dress codes says boys can not have hair longer than 1 inch. He does not know what is important when it comes to educating students."
"This school is getting better by each day that passes," writes former student, Felicia Reyes.

I attended PS 28 from 1963 to 1968.  It was only 4 blocks north of my old home on Anthony Avenue and Prospect Place.  The man in charge back then was Principal Golden.  Was also a member of the local Navy Cadet group that met in the basement cafeteria every Wednesday evening. But my best memories were of my all time favorite teacher Mrs. Suarez.  Back then it had the resources for after school sessions, summer camp and such.  It was mostly white but that changed between the late 60's to mid 70's when the imfamous 'white flight' was in full bloom.

My child has went to this school for the 3rd grade and From what I see it SUCKS! Her SETTS teacher from last year did NOTHING! barely pulled her out, and it never helped. I got her retested and no improvement. My daughter is falling behind more. This school is a soon to be set up for drop out factories.

There are not enough self contained classrooms for the amount of students with special needs in this school.  Many of the students who truly need a smaller classroom  (e.g., 12:1:1) to achieve academic growth are placed in general education classes or collaborative team teaching classes.  To make up for not being placed in an appropriate classroom setting, they are given an extensive amount of PULL OUT special educational services.  The result...The students continue to fall behind because they are are being pulled out of the classes instead of being placed in the appropriate classroom setting.

PS .  Art was 20 minutes every other week at the classroom easels (two at a time). "I think I'm approachable. I have an open-door policy," said Principal Graciela Navarro, who started her public school career as a teacher's aide and worked her way through parent coordinator, teacher, and all the way up to principal. "I like to resolve conflicts through dialogue."
"It's changed a lot. We have Philippine, Vietnamese, Puerto Rican, Mexican, African children. It's very multi-cultural here," said an ESL teacher who has worked at the school for 24 years.

"This is a great school with a wonderful administration and amazing teachers that provide the students with many opportunities to explore their talents through the arts," writes parent Meisha Porter, who especially praises the school's parent coordinator, "who thinks of each child as her own."
When asked to explain why parent involvement was so strong, one PTA member answered: "This school gave so much to my kids that I want to give something back." (2003)

Hello everyone.  I don't know if writing this here matters but I am willing to try my best to get my unpopular opinion out.  The truth is this school does not do right by children and the staff.  We're supposed to pretend everything is ok, our principal is right a hundred percent of the time, and the children are perfect.  That is not the case.  PS 42 is a dysfunctional school because of it's leadership and the teachers who don't stand by the rights of the children.  There are many incidents swept under the rug, not documented, and/or ignored.  Children are being bullied in the class and especially at lunch.  It pains me because my father attended this school, I did, and now my daughter and it is a school with low expectations.  My daughter had glue poured on her uniform pants.  When I attempted to speak to the counselor, she was busy.  I spoke with Ms. Orduz, the principal, during dismissal and was told the matter would be resolved.  My daughter the next day complained that the student had attacked another one of my daughters peers without consequence.  I on my own reached out to the parent and was shocked to find out that she did not know about the incidents.  The mother was pleasant and heard me out but she also wondered why the school had not informed her.  When I dropped off my daughter the next day I let Ms. Velencia know I had spoken with the parent and told her that the parent did not know.  I asked why was the parent not informed and her response was, "We're busy planning trips."  

Where is this schools priorities?  What is it they value?  It starts at the top and Ms. Orduz has illustrated in my opinion bad leadership more times than I can count.

This is my 3rd year with the school and the teachers are cool and nice.  The principal is rude and disrespectful.  She's too weak on discipline often trying to hide situations that have happened.  For example when the student threw the laptops out of the window, the big brawl during lunch last year, the fight in the classroom.  There were no resolutions.  Talk to you kids.  The principal has no discipline.

The parent coordinator at this school is the biggest cheerleader for the principal.  My child was attacked in the middle of the hallway while the teacher was with the class.  I brought my concerns to Ms. Solis the parent coordinator.  She brought me to the guidance counselor.  Supposedly the issue was addressed.  Then my child was attacked by the same student during lunch.  I again spoke with Ms. Solis who referred me to the principal and her assistant principals.  Again I was assured the issue would be addressed.  Then a couple of weeks later my child was punched in his back during lunch time.  I asked my child who was watching the class, he stated that no one was watching the class because the assistant principal was showing the lady that was supposed to watching the class something on her cellphone.

I again spoke with Ms. Solis about the lack of supervision for both children and adults.  Ms. Solis went on a long tangent about how Ms. Orduz rewards children, there are all these wonderful trips, Ms. Orduz cares.  What does that have to do with my concerns.  I'm worried about my child.  The job of a parent coordinator is to create a welcoming school environment for parents and helping to address parents’ concerns.  Not be the personal cheerleader for the principal.  How can there be improvements if you are in denial about about is going wrong?  The lack of supervision is quite troubling.

PS 42 is unorganized.  It is difficult to have a legit conversation with the principal about student progress because she tries to win you over by being nice.  The assistant principal is clueless.  It's very accurate that if you attend a low preforming elementary school you will most likely end up in a low preforming middle school.  Where does that lead, to a low preforming high school.  I have nothing against the principal but she comes off as delusional when you attempt to speak to her about real topics.  You can't make any suggestions because she has all the answers and is very defensive.  Various teachers, not just my daughter's teacher,  have shared with me how frustrated they are with the lack of support and  chaos at the school.  Ms. Orduz needs help in organizing her priorities or the school will continue to fail.  Look at the data it speaks for itself.  See how many people think it could be better.  Make unannounced visits to witness children running around the school building, staff playing on their phones, fights, and children screaming out of frustration.  Claremont we deserve better.

ps.42 so far has been a great help with teaching and supporting our kids.my favorite thing about ps.42 is how they have events for parents to be involved with what their child is learning and show parents games and materials they can do with their child at home.
This is my fourth year as a parent I find the teachers nice and knowledgeable and always helpful.
I like how explain everything and help alot. I like ps 42 and good teachers.
This is a really good school and my kids are learning a lot. The teachers communicate with the parents. The parents are always welcome anytime in the school.

I love the activities the school have for the students. I like teach me Tuesdays . the after school program the school for the concerts for the holidays. The festivals, movie nights and bingo nights are really fun. I like to participate in the week that the Phys Ed teachers invite the parents in to participate in gym class. This helps you get to know the students and the staff better. it really help me as well to continue this!

Since my son has been in this school I have always liked the attention they have given me and my son. I love the dedication of the teachers and the supervisors. I would love for my son to continue to finish his elementary education here.

I disagree.  I believe that is a part of the problem.  That they don't.  Only 31% and 30% scored a 3 or 4 on state test.  Below the city average.  When I have talked to the school counselor about my daughters academic progress, she's clueless.  I met with the assistant principal and she focused on incidents that did not involve my child and made me began questioning the structure of class and consequences. Why do you think there are so many fights?  Many children walking out of class and disturbing others.  I wish this school were more organized and had better structure.
I like teach me Tuesday at this school. I like to learn from the teachers how to help my daughter. The teachers are nice.

This is my second year here at PS 42 and my experience has been nothing but positive. I find the principal to be understanding, reliable and have nothing but the best interest for her students and staff. Just like at any school, students will disagree and argue, but bullying and fighting is not a focus at this school. Students are taught to act with respect and care for one another. As a school, teachers promote positive values and morals for students through their actions as leaders. Teachers are there for students and take the time to get to know and understand the children.

If you attend a low performing elementary school it leads to most likely being matched to a low performing middle school which then you end up in a low performing high school. 

My biggest frustration is I attempted to work with the counselors at this school.  They were overwhelmed with children fighting.  I reached out to the principals and they never got back to me.

I’m so disappointed but I will continue to fight for my sons education.  Even though my son does not attend PS 42 anymore, he is still dealing with consequences of their unorganization and chaos.

I have a wierd relationship with this school.  I love the teachers but the Principals need to go especially Ms. Orduz.  Anyone that has ever sat in a meeting with knows she does not know anything.  How can you be a principal and not be respected by the children, their parents, and the community.  

Ms. Orduz is excellent at head nods and staring into space.  I have been involved in three meetings with her and she appears to be disconnected.  I have requested to meet with the parents of a child that is bullying my son.  I have told Ms. Orduz I do not blame the parents but perhaps us meeting will help.  I never got my meeting.  Instead I was fortunate enough to meet with the guidance team and the Principals.  Ms. Orduz stared into space and whenever the assistant principal spoke shook her head.  Complete waste of everyone’s time.  

My sons teacher then told me, Ms. Orduz said she is tired of meeting with that crazy parent and my whiny son.  Is that how a principal conducts herself?

I have some concerns.  About this school my son Is a student of this school I can honestly say  his first yr was. Good.but when the second yr  came around I started to lose trust in the school the principal's barely knows my son, just this past yr I called the DOE cuz I felt my son education was being neglected the teacher played favortisam my wife went to the teacher numbers times and she has always talked short and sometimes has  attitude like who cares. One time we received a progress report and I ask for a personal meeting and I was told that the report was self- explanatory and a meeting wouldn't be necessary like my son and his needs wearing important all to her ,so we met with the teacher and the assistant principal of my son's grade and during the meeting we were told that even if he's sick we should try to bring him to school and my son suffers from severe asthma and I explained that if he's having trouble breathing he is unable to focus properly in the classroom because he has trouble breathing she said I quote does a doctor tell you that he cannot come to school and I said if he cannot breathe he cannot be in school and she said maybe an hour or two he can I'm giving the school benefit of a doubt if nothing changes this yr his future would be grim with this school .

This is difficult for me.  I do not even how to begin.  I did not know of this website but I am happy to have discovered it thanks to the Assistant Principal Ms. Velez.  Ms. Velez asked me to come here and basically promote PS 42, my son's school.  I can see why so many people have expressed frustration over the prinicipals playing politics.  

I am grateful to Ms. Velez for trying to help me countless times, but I cannot lie on her behalf.  The truth is I have met with her various times this year already because of my son is being bullied and attacked, especially in the cafeteria.  I appreciate Ms. Velez attempting to help me and meeting with me, but that does not merit me lying on her and the schools behalf.  Truth is I don't know how I feel after I left her room that day which is why I am expressing myself here.  Perhaps some of the other parents have had similar experiences or may be not.  

I do know that something needs to change at this school and there seems to be a disconnect between some of the parents and the staff.  The staff is under the impression that everything is great at this school.  It isn't.  Teachers need to be more strict with their classes, the prinicpals need to be respected, and bad behaved students should not be negotiated with.

My children have attended P.S. 42.  I have a daughter who is now graduating from the 5th grade.  She has excelled in this school and has become a leader in her own right.  She has had excellent teachers and I can not complain.  The prinicpal and her staff care very much for the children in the school.  I can never say that I had a bad experience with any staff member or the children always have a smile.  I would recommend this school to anyone.  It is one of the best schools in District 9.

I disagree with Ms. Solis.  My kids attend PS 42 and there is a lot of room for improvement.  Only 18% of 3rd, 4th, and 5th graders scored a 3 or 4 on the Math test.  The city average is 39%.  13% of those students scored a 3 or 4 on the Reading.  The city average is 30%.  On the state Science test for 3rd and 4th graders 59% scored on grade level.  The city average is 82%.  0% of students with disabilities are on grade level.  The city average is 8%.  

PS 42 is extremely under performing and failing our community.

The principal is rude and very arrogant.  I found it very difficult to speak with her and her securities.  I did not appreciate when she told her securities that my special needs child and I needed to speak to the special school upstairs and laughed about it.  She is very insensitive.
In 2013 only 8% of the students were on grade level.  Last year, with the Prinicpals efforts it's gone up to 10%.  Not enough!

I'm one of many teachers being forced out due to politics in the last two years.  The parents don't even realize what is happening.  This year I went above and beyond my duties at this school and the principal targeted me ultimately forcing me to leave.  The current environment is politics over student achievement.

My daughter who is in second grade complains of headaches, due to the noise in the classroom. I have complained to the Principal countless times. I have been referred to the assistant principal who does not know what she is doing. The
worst part is that students are rewarded no matter how they behave. How is that fair to students like my daughter? The system at PS 42 is broken and teachers are letting out students down.

PS 42 has no consistent system of rules and consequences, high turnover (the best leave), a dangerous school environment, and teachers (the ones that can't find a job anywhere else) that participate in verbal abuse. I'm a frustrated parent worried about my daughter and her friends. Sadly I was extremely happy with this school two years ago, but because so many of the talented employees have left the school is going down hill. I don't feel comfortable with my daughter attending this school and plan on making this her final year. Sadly the children are bullying each other in a consistent basis with no real consequences for the bullies... kids that walk out of their class, and curse at other students and teachers...are given toys and candy...as part of behavior plan. I live at 500 East 171st Street and am so disappointed to my daughter is zoned for PS 42.

The paraprofessionals at this school are deplorable.  As a parent who has been inside the building on numerous occasions in recent years, I have seen their laziness and harshness. In every one of my visits the para likes to sit in a corner of the room staring off into space, sending text messages or making cell phone calls..  Other habits include socializing with any staff member that happens to walk by the room and telling the special education kids that they are hateful.  The more I think about this the more I think I should call 311.  People like to badmouth teachers but, really, these paras should have an evaluation system and earn tenure.  30, 40K yearly for doing nothing and acting like a savage is an outrage.

In five years of subbing I came across a lot of paras like that.  I used to tell them that even though I told the kids to stay in their seats during class, the paras could still walk around the room.  They usually didn't take the hint.
I wish ps42 would send letters by mail to parents homes because some kids don't bring informative letters like when school starts or after school programs

"We hold everyone to a high expectation," says Principal Collin Wolfe.

A May 20, 2005 New York Times article by reporter David Herszenhorn about big gains in the number of 4th graders meeting state reading and writing standards notes that at PS 53 4th grade ELA test scores rose 19.5 points in one year, with 56.1 percent of the students meeting standards.  The article quotes PS 53 principal, Collin M. Wolfe as saying the school doesn't  "do test prep.  We teach children content. We teach them strategies. We teach them meta-cognitive skills so they can become independent learners." Wolfe adds: "The mantra in my school is we are not preparing children for the test, we are preparing them for life."
PS 55 students are part of the Health Department's "Active Design in Schools" project, which promotes physical activity using murals and art, News 12 reports.
MindBodyGreen highlights the benefits of PS 55's farming curriculum, including high attendance rates and increased attitudes towards health.

Stephen Ritz said he and his students have grown more than 30,000 pounds of vegetables over the last eight years. The longtime teacher of PS 55 and founder of the non-profit Bronx Green Machine is determined to change the lives of disadvantaged students, one garden at a time. Read more here.

A teacher at PS 55 is one of 10 finalists for a $1 million Global Teaching Prize. Stephen Ritz, who teaches science, founded a notprofit that has led to the creation of over 100 community gardens at New York City schools. Read more here.

PS 55 Benjamin Franklin has been selected to participate in the Department of Education's Community Schools initiative, aimed at boosting attendance and achievement by bringing in community partners to provide support for students and families. I used to go to that school, and i can honestly say that it has changed dramatically. My little brothers and sister go to the school now, and though there may e some problems, at least there aren't as many as before. You can't really use outside forces to determine what is going on inside the school. I mean, what school is really that perfect anyway, all schools are going to have their problems.

Sad to say but this school hasn't changed at all. I went to school in manhattan and only moved to the Bronx 7 years ago already out of high school. My 6 year old went to Pre-K and is currently in Kindergarten at PS 55 ( not by choice as this is his zone school, i would've preferred a school in the city) . there is absolutley no parent involvment. Along with myslef there are maybe a handful of parents that seem to show they actually care. The school tries to camoflouge their reality with pretty painted walls instead of  worrying about their students! Their is also a huge bullying issue at this school. Within my son's first two months of school there, i witnessed 6 incidents where there was a group of 12-13 yearolds beating up on one kid , another when a smaller child keeps his head down while a bigger kid is hitting his head from behind. Mind you this all occurred in the presence of teachers and other school officials, imagine whats going on when there is no adult present. Teachers and security guards looked burned out as they wait till last minute to dicipline a child. There is no diciplinary actions at this school. as far as academics goes, i recieved a letter from DOE teling me that PS 55 is a School In Need of Improvement and a Persistently Lowest Achieving School and has giving me the chioce to choose any Elementary School, city wide for my son to attend. I will defintly be getting my child out of this school. if you truly want your child to prosper and explore and truly  learn in a safe and nurturing environment DO NOT SEND YOUR CHILD TO THIS SCHOOL!!!!!!!!!!!

In a couple of months you will be returning back to the school. No other schools provides the supports provided at PS 55. The school has a health clinic, gives families clothing, and provides a rich educational program. How many PA meetings did you attend? Okay time to move on.

actually i have moved on...to a much better school in manhattan! a school where they don't give the excuse of "gang activity" for reasons of poor quality. also his new school also has a health clinic too. my younger son will bestarting kindergarten next fall, and if he can't get into his brothers school, and i told he must go to his zoned school, believe i'd rather home school him! and u can't really say that it's a rich educational experience when the DOE has declared it a needs of improvement school. that's not a good thing, they actually put my child in the no child left behind program and gave him the opportunity to choose another school! even the DOE believes my son would benefit from going to another school too! Do ur research, PS 55 in failing! hopefully this year those test scores in be up!!!

Many teachers at this school try to do their jobs in an environment that no one else would even undertake.  You really should provide a context how this school is in the midst of public housing projects and how the gangs monitor the comings and goings of staff and students. The principal is forced to travel home using different routes because the gangs have considered him a threat.  I know many people expect "Superman" to make everything right in a school and if this school had enough money (budget cuts) to improve safety concerns you would see a dramatic difference.  However, when did teachers become police officers and social workers and most importantly parents.  Why are teachers expected to teach children how to behave in a classroom and why its important to listen and respect adults that keep you safe?  Why are parents not being held accountable for allowing their children to behave in such an atrocious manner? The parents at the school should stop deifying the streetlife/thug/gangster/bad girl way of being and put more energy into raising responsible citizens.  Most of these kids would have a culture shock if they were placed in a school where the parents promoted different values. BTW there is another school that shares space with 55 and the parents have their kids act in a responsible manner and it permeates that school's culture.  Same building, same community, different parents. The neighborhood is DANGEROUS and that is why you should not send your kids to the school.  STOP BASHING EDUCATORS.

I simply stated facts. and i do agree with you that the problems underlines at home with parents not teaching their children how to behave, but as teachers  it shouldn't just be about teaching their students curriculum, but also about responsibility. Teachers can really have an influence on children. i've seen that first hand.  I see how some parents talk to their children and the way they themselves behave with them and i admit it truly disgusts me! i assure you my son is raised as a respectful innocent 6 year old.  I never said the prinicpal should be a superman either. instead of getting offended as a educator, read my comment again. also as teachers you are with the children the the majority of their day so yeah, i believe that teachers should try to act not only as educators but diciplinaries, if the issue escalates, well thats what the security guards are there for. As the Parent Coordinator for this school I take the time to review comments that are made and value the positive reviews as much as I do those where concerns are expressed.  I further take the opportunity to work with the families as well as the administration to rectify concerns as the principal has charged me with that responsibility.  He meets with me, members of the PA as well as the SLT, to address issues that arise regularly as he likes to address concerns immediately.  To that end he holds an open door policy and parents as well as staff know how accessible he is to them as well as the community.  In looking at my records, Ms. Rodriguez, your schedule did not allow for you to attend any parent meetings nor did you attend Parent Teacher Conferences.  Also, every Tuesday afternoon you had an opportunity to meet with your child’s teacher as well as the administration and you did not exercise that right.  At these meeting you would have learned about the promotional criteria as well as the benchmarks that students should be approaching throughout the school year.  Progress reports go out to the families every five –six weeks removing the element of surprise.  As for the administration goes, they are very friendly and down to earth yet they have high expectations

Strong leadership? Not. Leadership--quite the contrary. There is no leadership in this administration. However, there IS dictatorship! Teacher's are not allowed to explore and try various strategies that perhaps may close a child's academic achievement gap solely because administration does not agree with the approach. This administration is NOT for the kids, only for numbers; the number of children who will possibly achieve a 3 or 4. Students are held back in the school for 2 or 3 years consecutively. Why? because they're not at reading level.. this will NOT "look" good on their state scores. They are rude and nasty towards their staff members. They are constantly hiring new teachers every year, due to mistreatment towards teachers. Teachers are never acknowledged or appreciated. This school is more out to "get" you, as opposed to help you grow. 

DON'T WORK HERE.

Successful English as a Second Language teacher, Sobrique Grant, was featured in the New York Times in a series of interviews with New Yorkers holding entry level positions.

"Yes, CES 70 is a huge place, but the staff makes it feel like home" by nurturing and supporting the students, writes Karen Tavarez, a teacher. "Mr. Singer is always open and willing to listen to what educators and parents have to say. The building is old but as a team we always try to keep the place neat."

"Lunch extends over three periods from 10:50 to 12:30," writes a teacher, about the recent reorganization. "Grades split the lunch hour: one grade goes to recess while the other eats lunch and then they switch. This has been an improvement. Class sizes, however, are way too large at 29-33. Though these numbers may not exceed the "legal" class size limit, but it is very difficult to meet the tremendous needs the students present. The school does not hire substitute teachers to cover absences, so an uncovered class (or two) will be spilt up. This places an undue burden on the teachers. The school needs to hire subs!"

The principal did not respond to the above comment.

"Kids need more counseling, some of these kids have issues, so do their parents. We also need more security guards. One guard isn't enough for a school this size," says Yara Contes, vice president of the Parents Association. "

We have an excellent principal. The school has a real community feeling and it trickles down from the top," says a teacher, Jessica Reitmyer.

"I am always having to tidy up my classroom. They just do cursory sweeping and they mop maybe twice a year. That is why kids get sick," says Catherine Szpunt, a teacher.
PS 73 Bronx is one of 14 schools that received funding to become a model dual-language school in New York City. Read more here.
PS 73 has been selected as a model school for dual-language programs and will receive $10,000 for staff training and teaching materials. Read more here.

Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced that 15 schools with existing Dual Language programs will become Model Dual Language Programs, including PS 73, for the 2015-16 school year. The schools will receive $10,000 for multilingual instructional materials and staff will have ongoing professional development. Read more here.
The dual language program at PS 73 will begin in pre-kindergarten, as of September 2015.

"A group of parents is working against violence, incidents, security, safety and verbal abuse inside of this school," writes parent Jose Gonzales. At PS 109 first graders in a new service program say they've never been in a garden until this year, but now the school has two full-time staff members dedicated to teaching them all about food. Read more here.

Chancellor Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. PS 214 was chosen to host P.S. 109 Sedgwick and P.S. 143 Louis Armstrong. Read more here.

This was my Elementary school. I'm now 24. 

Part of my great childhood is in this school.  The staff were great.  This school opened my eyes to the unlimited possibilities a person can have.  The staff really helped me realize that there was a big world out there for me to discover.  

I love a lot of the staff that was there.  Especially Ms. Schweitzer, who I believe is retired now.  They were my friends and people that I could turn to... at age 7.

If you child goes here, I think they will get adequate attention.  But it starts with YOU! Be involved in the school. It is YOUR school too.  It is a community.  PLEASE don't take this as an okay to be in constant communication with your childs teachers.  If you do, your child will not like you for it. Be yourself and grow with the school. Take a day to volunteer at some school function at the school.  Express your concerns to the parent coordinator and the principal of the school.  Please, do not overshadow your kids!! I am primarily speaking to the single child parents who are raising their child by themselves. Your child will not develop to be a strong willed, self-aware being if you are always there.  Children are um.... kids but sometimes they can be the most clearest zen-like little adults and you do not want to hinder their development by protecting them from everything. (taking a breath)

It is nice that the school is away from major avenues.  The school sits at one of the highest points in the Bronx. In my book, places in the highest points of any terrain is the best place to be (and if I'm not mistaken, through out history, the rulers, educators, nobles and wealthiest people lived at high terrains).

The school is small but it has space for everything.  It has two yards (wow I had a lot of fun there) a Gym, computer rooms, Auditorium, Cafeteria and library.  I always remember the building being very clean.  I've been to some schools that were not as clean.  The building has a layout that I've always liked.  

After school was great.  DODGEBALL!!!! The first time I publicaly danced was in that school!!!! Amazing.  Wow, I am turning 7 as I write this.

This is a good school.  Tell your kids to get A's only.  There is help and support for them to do so AT ANY school.  Tell your kids to ask the principal for anything.

This is a really good school.

"This is a friendly school. We need more parent involvement, but it is coming along," says Parent Coordinator Milagros Rivera. She cites as one example of increased involvement the dozen or so parents who are training to become official classroom volunteers.

A prospective parent writes: "In April, I called the principal of 109, Ms. Schweitzer, and without reservation she accommodated our visit. She graciously agreed to give us a tour of the kindergarten classes. A week later we visited and she personally gave us a tour of the kindergarten classes. As we walked through the school learning was going on in each and every classroom. Students were well behaved the hallways and classrooms were covered with students' work. This is evidence that raising the self-esteem of the students is an important mission in this school. It is not surprising the school has great math and reading scores. Ms. Schweitzer displayed pride in her school and had kind words about all of her teachers. I am confident that this is the right school for our son. Bravo for Ms. Schweitzer!"

More than 50 honor roll students at PS 114 got a pleasant surprise when they showed up for what they thought was a safety presentation in the school auditorium, News 12 The Bronx reports. In addition to safety tips the students each got a bicycle fromthe Police Department's 44th Precinct as a reward for the children's grades and good behavior.
Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña convened a group of principals at schools that enroll a high percentage of homeless students for a conversation to share ideas and best practices, Politico reported.
PS 114's Dr. Aaron is one of 113 literacy coaches the city enlisted to reach the mayor's target 100% literacy rate for public school students by 2026, the Wall Street Journal reports.
Just thirteen percent of PS 114 students passed state tests in English language arts, the Wall Street Journal reports.

Teacher Keila Merino is challenging herself to break a world record running from Los Angeles to New York City. She hopes to inspire her students and try to raise money for New York Road Runners Mighty Milers free youth running program. Read more here.
Fourth-grade teacher Keila Merino moonlights as a serious long distance runner and is using her experience to begin running programs at the school. Read more here.

Reading this makes me very sad.  I went to this school in the early 60s and my memories are nothing like what I am reading.  Also, the education I received as stellar, putting me far ahead of my counterparts when I moved to Las Vegas in 1966.  I know the neighborhood and demographics have changed, but NY should take care of these kids and provide them a better opportunity to excel when they become adults.

I am a former principal in NYC and a current leadership development consultant who works all over the Northeastern Seaboard. I just have to say that from the moment I walked in this school to provide a training for teachers from this school and schools in their network, the experience was phenomenal.  Perhaps it's time for an updated review, because I saw nothing smelly or unwelcoming, in fact it was just the opposite. Perhaps most importantly, every member of the staff from teachers to administrators were invested in learning together, and it's clear that they go above and beyond to create an environment conducive to learning for all participants in their network.  The common spaces held evidence of both student learning and adult learning. Granted, it's hard to know everything about any community on a quick visit, but the experience I had in this school was impressive and deserves to be noted. Kudos to Principal Olivia Francis-Webber and recognition must go to the multimedia specialist, Arc Handwerger, for maintaining a phenomenal learning space for kids and adults alike.

IS 117 has been removed from the State Education Department's list of struggling schools and no longer faces possible receivership at the end of the 2015-2016 school year. Politico New York reports.
IS 117 is one of three city schools at risk of being handed over to an independent receiver by the end of the year if test scores and graduation rates don't improve. Read more here.

Sixty-two NYC schools could be taken over by outside groups within two years, and seven of those even sooner. IS 117 has been designated “Persistently struggling,” and now has a one-year deadline. Read more here.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,”. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.

Parents at I.S. 117 are working on requests for the principal. This list includes better security at the exits, more arts and sports programs and more counseling for kids and families. Read more here.

Second graders at PS 163 illustrate haiku poems using bright colors to depict landscapes, birds, snails, turtles and other images found in the poems. The poems are the work of Sydell Rosenberg, a former public school teacher, ESL teacher and founding member of the Haiku Society of America. Ms. Rosenberg passed away in 1996.

Ms. Rosenberg’s daughter, Amy Losak, pitched the idea to Arts for All, a non-profit organization that brings many forms of art to public school kids, including music, theater and dance. These workshops are designed to help children develop stronger reading, writing and speaking skills.

Losak believed that her mother’s concise, compact yet highly evocative haiku – many populated with animal and children “characters” and conjuring seasonal and scenic themes -- could facilitate visual thinking and other forms of artistic expression. Read more about The Haiku Project here: http://bit.ly/Utu09k

Walls are coming!  Construction started in the fall and will take about 2 years to be completed.  There are four large "open" classrooms which will be divided into four classrooms each (the same number of classes currently in each open classroom, separated by cubicle partitions).  Construction is proceeding on one open classroom at a time, with the four classes normally housed in that space relocated throughout the building.  It is very cramped, but the end result will be worth it.
"I wish the walls would go all the way up so we could concentrate," said one 3rd grader.
"I like it because the teachers aren't mean," said one 3rd grader.
"The teachers are great. I can do art, and reading, and science," said one 2nd grader. She added: "The pizza is the only thing good [to eat in the cafeteria.]"
"If you want to smile and be happy all the time, come to PS 163," wrote one 3rd grader.
"I wish we didn't have lunch at 1 o'clock. I wish we had it a 12," said one 3rd grader.

A visitor to the school notes, "Former Principal Ramuni was very committed to the use of technology in the school, curriculum and community. Since his departure, the computers in class rooms remain unused and in a state of disrepair."

This comment is outdated, if it was ever true in the first place.  All classrooms are equipped with 4-8 laptops, a projector, document camera, and SMART Board, which are used on a daily basis.  Most teachers are very tech-savvy.

Stephen, a former student writes: "I went to school at CES 163 for five years. I had many fun experiences at that school. Now, I am in the sixth grade, thankful for what I got at C.E.S 163. The teachers were understanding, and the principal was your best friend. There were out-of-class lessons. Field trips. Seldom were there any problems and when there were, you could bet that another one would not occur for about six weeks."

"I grew up on the same block that CES 163 is located on and I attended kindergarten through third grade there," writes an alumnus. "I remember it being a special school where the teachers really cared about the students education. I'm glad to see that it is finally being recognized as an institution that produces success."

A mother whose son moved to the school from Queens after kindergarten noted that her son was not properly evaluated until he came to 163. "I knew he was having problems but I did not know what they were," she said. "I see the progress he has made in reading and writing." (2002)

"The teachers are new and young and they seem to care about the kids but they don't seem to get much support from the administration," writes a parent. This parent complains that class sizes are large; the morning routine is disorganized, resulting in a situation where "recently, the children were forced to line up outside even in the cold and rain"; there are few school events; and there are "no after school programs except for bi-weekly tutoring for students who are doing very poorly."

"I have visited this school 3 times over the past 3 years," writes the parent of a teacher. "My daughter is the teacher for a new program 'Passport to New York' which has a goal of broadening the students' experience by teaching them the history of and exposing them to the rich culture of New York City via class lessons which culminate in an appropriate field trip. I am pleased that the principal is supportive of innovative attempts to widen the horizons of students at the Shakespeare School."

PS 204 is one of eight schools in low-income neighborhoods with a "gifted and talented" program starting in 3rd grade, The Wall Street Journal reports.  "Teacher Matt Jordan said children benefit from collaborating with advanced peers, instead of feeling like outliers," the Journal said, adding. "'Our biggest problem,” he said, is having to say 'come on, guys, you’ve got to put away your books now.'... The children ‘’all have this common denominator of knowledge and wisdom, so you can just take it to the next level,' said Amanda Blatter, principal of P.S. 204. “They’re excelling.” https://www.wsj.com/articles/gifted-programs-in-high-poverty-districts-aim-to-create-pipeline-to-opportunity-11549717200?mod=hp_listc_pos5

A former teacher who was at the school for four years writes that she did not return because of frustrations with the administration. She describes teachers at the school as "dedicated," but writes that "The "dual language" program is a catastrophe. It has been implemented in a haphazard and thoughtless way over the last few years, with some classes receiving instruction in both languages and others not." She describes what she sees as some of the problems with the duel language program, including inadequate training for teachers. "Your profile of the school says that students receive reading, writing and math instruction only in English. In the first place, that is inconsistent with a dual language model, and in the second place, it is wrong. For two years I taught language arts only in Spanish, and this year my former students (fourth graders!) have so far received language arts instruction only in Spanish," she writes. She criticizes the administration of the school's special education program as well. "An understanding of good pedagogy and a willingness to hear other voices are crucial, and both are lacking among 218's administrators. When decisions are made at the last minute, with incomplete or incorrect knowledge, and with no regard for the preferences and ideas of teachers and parents, tremendous potential is wasted all around."

"This school is an okay school," writes a student.

"Rafael Hernandez, while in theory a dual language magnet school, does not provide students with a dual language program," writes a former teacher who continues to be in contact with teachers from the school. "This was the case during my two years at the school and continues to hold true. There were other significant gaps in the curriculum: art, music, gym, even basics such as social studies and science were not consistently provided to students. Rafael Hernandez also has significant problems with teacher morale largely due to an unsupportive administration. This low morale, in addition to poor scheduling and curriculum choices, has a detrimental effect on 218 students. Ultimately the resulting difficulties lead many teachers to leave the school causing a high turnover rate and leaving inexperienced teachers in the classroom." She adds, "I was also aware of many parents who expressed concerns and frustrations regarding their students education and the lack of response on the part of the administration. Rafael Hernandez is a school with a great deal of potential, but it is currently being wasted."

"It is puzzling that CES 218 has such a high teacher turnover rate," writes a teacher. "It is a shame that a school with such potential to serve the South Bronx is beset by what teachers identify as a lack of administrative accountability. Resources such as a $200,000 TV studio go unused" and "dedicated teachers report a hostile work environment."
