My son is a part of the inaugural middle school class at the
flagship Eagle Academy for Young Men, and we will not be returning for high school (something that was decided very early in our experience with the school). After almost 3 years as a parent of an Eagle middle school student, note that this is my opinion based on my experience, and I am sure that many can offer a complete opposite observation.  Forgive the long post, but here it goes…

As a parent who was excited to be a part of what Eagle claim
to offer its scholars, their families and the community at large, I was excited to join the family. I thought that it would be a good place for my son to be during such a transitional part of his life (middle school, puberty, expanded independence, etc.). The idea of being surrounded on a daily basis by intelligent and influential men of color – something that isn’t shoved down our throats via the media especially - was a welcome experience. I also looked forward to the ideas of structure, the uniform policy, and the fact that this
was a single gender institution. There would also be a mentor’s program that the boys were required to take part in and many other activities that would make Eagle more about an “experience” as opposed to just going to school. And while I think we were all gung ho about this mission that we would take together, to introduce our boys/scholars to the possibilities, the actual execution of these goals have left a lot to be desired in my experience as a parent of an Eagle middle schooler.

There is an impression that I got that always bothered me
when attending the bi-monthly parent meetings – an air of superiority and half-truths being fed to the masses when – if you peeked behind the curtain, things were not being run as portrayed when someone is on the open mic. Teachers would boast about how available they are – via email, telephone, whenever – and how they give homework every night, when in practice that is not the norm. There are some teachers who, despite the rock and the hard place they find themselves in oftentimes, make the effort, but the ones who do not make their staff look bad as a whole. Some have a dismissive attitude that has often had me looking at them like “well, if you’re like this with me - an adult – then I can imagine how you communicate with my son when I’m not looking.”

Oh, and that wonderful online email system – Pupil Path/ Skedula – that is such a wonderful tool that can keep us all involved and up to
date with our child’s progress…the one where you can send and receive emails, check out their grades…see “real time” progress…it’s not a requirement for teachers to use, they don’t all use it, many don’t check email (one teacher told me that for practically half of this school year his “email didn’t work”, and sometimes the grades for assignments aren’t posted until just before the marking period grades are due… when it’s too late to do anything about it. In addition, school work is not sent home after it’s graded, so I ask quite pointedly, how do I help my son study if I can’t see his work and the teacher
comments until parent-teacher conference which, to reiterate, is too late as far as the marking period is concerned?

Frustration with new the Common Core standards way of teaching has been the thorn in everyone’s side. Teachers still don’t know how
to teach it, and we parents – who did not learn in this manner – have a difficult time helping them with their work. I understand the Common Core standards in theory, but in practice it has been a difficult pill to swallow for all involved. With that understood, as an adult and a professional, there is something called appropriate behavior despite whatever frustrations one is experiencing. 

The assistant principals really are the foot soldiers who, I think, are trying their best to do what they can, but why do I have to keep
running to the assistant principals because the dean or teachers are ignoring emails or phone calls and messages?

The staff’s idea of what is and isn’t bullying is an essay that I won’t write at this time, but as a parent of a student who has had his
possessions taken from him (in front of a teacher) and thrown down the stairs, and in a separate incident, a bag of glitter dumped over his head in art class – I am beyond sick and tired of the adults not following up with ME. If I ask what the status is on something, tell me SOMETHING. I actually don’t expect resolutions to most of the incidents that go on there, but tell me something.

I made attempts to reach out to teachers when my son was out
sick, in an attempt to get work for him to do and I have heard nothing from any of them. I copy the dean – nothing! I sent the email as an FYI to the assistant principals and the parent coordinator – a woman who has doggedly worked and has truly been the people’s champion – just so they can see  that the very communication and involvement
that the teachers ask of us parents goes ignored.

I stopped going to the parent meetings for this very reason. And as a parent I own the fact that I am in some way disappointing my son by not involving myself in anything at the school anymore, but I have long since grown tired of hearing the speeches, hearing about how former Mayor Bloomberg and his administration supported the efforts of the school, hearing about how another school is going up somewhere else like a new Starbucks, when the flagship school has yet to “work out the kinks” to make it the place that a lot of us hoped for. I hate that my attitude has changed from “go team, go” to “let’s just get through the rest of the year.”

And while my own disappointments are that – my own – the boys
are the ones caught in the crossfire. 

Parent involvement has always been something that I have always
marveled over – parents show up to those meetings in droves (unlike myself this current school  year – I admit that I gave up trying to navigate through so much BS), but it is so encouraging and I
wish them the best. Their attendance alone shows that there are more people still ready and willing to make things better than not.

Good luck to everyone at the school or those considering
attending. I wish everyone the best and hope that if anything, the level of true, honest communication gets better because the only way we are going to help our boys to achieve the things that we hope for them is to work together.

Two years ago, I posted the wonderful review below about Eagle Academy after the completion of my son's first year.  Sadly, I have to agree with you to some extent........Eagle has changed.  I too, have had some negative experiences with some of the faculty and administrative staff.  Though the sixth grade was wonderful, the two following years grew progressively worse!  The eighth grade was particularly frustrating with more than one teacher/administrator, resulting in my husband and I deciding in the end to hire a private tutor to assist my son with his studies.  In all fairness, I have to add that I have found quite a few teachers and administrators who are caring and willing to go above and beyond to assist with issues.  I, personally, have had individuals who were not directly involved be the ones to offer the greatest level of support and assistance with finding a resolution to my issues.  

I don't think that any school will air their deficiencies to prospective students and parents, so I never expect such.  I also understand that while Eagle may LIKE to only accept the cream-of-the-crop students (wouldn't every school), they are a public school bound by NYC Dept. of Education rules and regulations, as well as working to uphold the mission of 100 Black Men (which founded Eagle Academy) to serve a population of minority students that are often "lost" within the educational system.  This may also mean that students who academically inclined to do well and/or are from more stable family backgrounds are exposed to others that are not like minded.  Look at the admissions criteria:  Priority for admissions is given to Bronx residents, and those that attend an information session.  Not the strictest standards.  They try to do their best with the students they have.

As a parent who has had experiences, both positive and negative, with charter schools, Catholic schools and public schools, I realize how difficult it has become to navigate something that was so much easier to do when I was a child.....get a good education!  Though my son is happy at Eagle, I am more worried about his preparedness for college.  I've let him know that as he enters high school, he has to begin to take control of his own destiny (I'm not letting go yet) and take responsibility for the things that will ensure him a brighter future.  If he fails to do so, then I will do it for him........and that will mean leaving Eagle.

Certainly, Eagle is not for every child.  No one school is.  But Eagle, in my opinion, does have its strengths.  I will remain active and supportive, make myself seen on a regular basis, and maintain my network of individuals within the school that I know to be supportive and reliable.  I am not solely relying on Eagle alone to prepare my son for college (my son is involved in extracurricular academic programs).  I let him stay because he wants to, but he also knows that if that feeling changes..........we can make change happen.

Good luck to all parents that are proactive in their quest for a good education for their children!  It's not easy, but it's not impossible.

It's a lot (for everyone), and I too wish the best of luck to all the students and staff.

Amidst the debate on charter schools, The New York Times held up the Eagle Academy schools as examples of successful hybrid schools, which which strive to offer low-income children something like the experience of a private education within the context of the traditional public system. However, after taking a closer look at the stats, Diane Ravitch argues that the Eagle Academy Schools shouldn't be portrayed as "miracle schools." Read more here.

Eagle Academy for Young Men is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.
Eagle Academy's founding principal, David Banks, defends single-sex education in the NY Daily News and describes his plans to open a new school in Harlem in September. Read more here.

Eagle Academy was named one of 20 schools picked for the city’s new Software Engineering Pilot program that will launch in September 2013. The program will include a comprehensive computer science and software engineering curriculum at each school. Read more here.

My son just completed a year at Eagle Academy (first 6th grade class).  I absolutely LOVE the dedication that the vast majority of teachers and administrators have for the scholars' academic success. Granted, while there are definitely some challenges related to student behavior (we are talking about a school full of boys from many walks of life), they seem to be dealt with appropriately by administration.  I always feel welcome, have had very positive communication experiences with his teachers, and most of all..........my son feels safe.  It truly is a "family" atmosphere, and I think that if you truly embrace Eagle Academy as "family" and immerse yourself in the school community, you not only see what they do wrong, but you also see firsthand what they are doing RIGHT!!
An administrator once told me that you should never try to fit your child to a school, but rather try to find a school that fits your child.  In my opinion, parents often want their child to attend a school because they think it's a "good school," and then they expect the school to do it all.  I think parents also need to consider whether their child "fits" Eagle because not all of the scholars easily adapt to the changes in a new school environment.  So if you think your son is a fit for Eagle and you, as the parent, are there to support the scholar and the school, he will be destined for success.  I think Eagle Academy For Young Men "rocks!"

TEACHER:  “100 BLACK MEN’S ELITE SCHOOL FALSELY IMPRISONED ME!”

New York City, December 22nd, 2010—Hal Lanse, a teacher at the elite Eagle Academy for Young Men, founded by the 100 Black Men of America, Inc. filed a lawsuit last week against the organization that included several shocking allegations.  “The principal, Osei Owusu-Afriyie, forced me to remain in a basement room denying me bathroom access.”  This, Lanse claims, was due to his union activism and the fact that he spoke out to the press when Owusu-Afriyie ordered teachers to change failing grades to passing.  “I was illegally transferred out of the school,” Lanse said. “When the Department of Education sent me back there, Owusu-Afriyie forced me to stay in the basement and personally closed the door on me on a day that the room reeked of vomit.”

“My client was also illegally suspended without pay for two weeks and not provided with COBRA health coverage, as proscribed by law,” said Linda Fox, Lanse’s attorney.  “The 100 Blacks proudly boast on their website that they founded the Eagle Academy,” Lanse said, “But I have been harassed and punished for exposing the school’s questionable practices.”

Don't be fooled by the school's exterior, it is highly dysfunctional. Students take a back seat to what makes the school look good. Whatever (if any) student success achieved is done in spite of the school, not because of it.

"Student success is done in spite of the school, not because of it."  Really? Statistics speak otherwise. AMS had a 96% graduation rate in its first cohort this June, compared to about a 50% average in other District 9 schools. Boston University*... Just saying.

For the first time in the school's history, ten students attended an engineering competition on April 4, 2009 at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). The students won third place for their machine design, out of 24 mostly suburban and private schools. The students, many of whom had never seen Boston, received a personal tour of MIT on Friday, competed on Saturday, and returned home on Sunday. The trip exposed students to an environment where praised engineers work in expensive high-tech labs, said Assistant Principal David Krulwich.

Principal Kenneth Baum received a 2009 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.

Students take the living environment Regents exam in 6th grade -- and many of them pass it, according to a column in the New York Times on July 5, 2006. About 43 percent of the 23 students who took the exam in 2006 passed with a 65 or higher, compared to 58 percent of all test-takers statewide. Most students take the test for the first time in 9th grade. Principal Kenneth Baum said in the article, "Our idea is that if we can make math and science fun and engaging and rigorous, then children will want to do it and achievement naturally follows."
A student praised the school's Saturday Academy and the individual academic assistance offered there.

"I have been to almost all of the community meetings concerning the Urban Assembly School and find it disturbing that one small segment of the larger Riverdale community is so hostile about [minority] children having a working public school in their own neighborhood," writes a Riverdale resident. She writes that she believes objections to the school are based on race and class.

According to an April 15, 2004 article in the Riverdale Review, Riverdale residents continue to be angered by the Department of Education's decision to place the Urban Assembly School for Math and Applied Science in the Whitehall Annex without consulting community members. The article reports: " Following two weeks of community outrage over The Urban Assembly School for Applied Math and Science, or the fun-math-school, placed secretly in the Whitehall Annex, the executive committee of Community Board #8 has approved a resolution demanding that the City Department of Education halt its placement of the fun-math-school in the Whitehall without community input." The article goes on to say that community members believe that if the space is going to be used for a school, it should house an early childhood education program. The article quotes Assemblyman Jeffrey Dinowitz explaining that residents would like to see the school placed in the new MS/HS 368 building instead.
New Pre-K dual language programs to add Spanish language programs to The New American Academy at Roberto Clemente State Park, according to NYC.gov.

What this school offers and what it is all about just can't be said with words. This school expanded my curiosity and widened my intelligence. This school has a variety of amazing staff, students, and classrooms. Once you place your feet on their floor, they treat you as if you were family. The school principal, Monica Brady (or as "Ms. Brady"), is an egalitarian. She believes that every single child on their floor, even the one's that aren't even their students, should truly know what love and family is. She also believes that the key to success is determination, passion, discipline (huge one), and commitment to achieve an objective. In this school I even learned, as a 2020 graduating 8th grader, that anything is possible, even the impossible. In life, to get what you want, where you want it, and how you want it, you must have enough ambition in order to get it. I can write millions and millions of paragraphs saying how amazing this school is, but I won't right now because it would take forever. The positive and nurturing climate is the greatest thing about my school. This school works very hard to create lasting memories through quality learning experiences and special events. That doesn't happen by accident. I really recommend this school to all students, grades 6 through 8, who are willing to strive further into becoming a better citizen in our world, a positive leader who will show other's how to be loving and passionate, and a person who is willing to make their future brighter. There is still time. There will always be. Even if it's 5.7 seconds left. But be sure to make it your best. Truly. Take the chance. The experience you will have at this school will change your life forever. Like it did to mine. 

Sincerely,

I graduated from 313 in 2006, and the review on this website describes my experience quite accurately. The use of metal detectors, brawls among students and schoolwide "lockdowns" were an everyday occurrence in the school. In retrospect, the strengths of the school are also remarkable. Students generally scored higher on standardized tests than students of neighboring school 339, despite possessing inferior technological resources. The faculty was exceptional (with a few exceptions). Teachers constructed lessons to encourage students to be active and thoughtful. Principal Wilkins was interactive with the student body, eager for input and personally acquainted with each student. All classes were relatively productive. The fights occurred when the students were not under supervision, during recess or lunch. Staff members (Mr. DeLaRosa &company) consistently encouraged students to excel. The school staff created an environment that encouraged students to succeed.

"I taught in this place in 2002. It seems like there is a principal that cares. It was an urban hell hole when I was there. I had kids sleeping heavy in class. They came from rambunctious disorderly homes. Field trips were to Rikers Island and nowhere else. I hope that they made soemthing of themselves. That was my first teaching job. It left an indleible mark on my life."

Parents, teachers and students ranked Bronx Early College Academy for Teaching and Learning the most improved city school, according to a June 25, 2009 article by the New York Daily News. The article credits John Barnes, the school's third principal in three years, as being part of the driving force behind the improvements. Barnes, who is known as a "superprincipal", or a principal brought in to turn around a struggling school, lengthened the school day and added clubs and after-school activities such as cheerleading and tennis, chess and art clubs.

"The Bronx Early College Academy is more than a school, it's a family. With a community of students, parents, teachers, administrators and staff that believe in the mission of BECA, this early college initiative school strives towards excellence. The BECA community is engaged in the accelerated learning program that provides the opportunity for the students to experience higher education and earn up to two years of college credits. My son had a great first year at BECA. The involvement and accessibility of the administration and teachers has made a difference in his educational experience. Executive Principal, John Barnes is an excellent leader and at the forefront of the school's transition towards ongoing increased success. Students at BECA take pride in their school and are very active and engaged in their learning. The strong parent involvement helps to create a family environment while strengthening the educational partnerships. BECA gets OUTSTANDING & A++!"

According to a July 7, 2008 New York Post article, "Parents at the Bronx Early College Academy were stunned to get a letter last week telling them the city's Department of Education can't find a building big enough for the growing sixth- through-12th-grade school." Like other CUNY prep-high schools, the school is meant to start in 6th grade and get their students ready for college work by the 11th grade. Ultimately, students should earn 60 college credits and their high school diploma at the same time. Parents worry the school's original goal won't be achieved. "We were told as parents this school would open from sixth to 12th," said Naminah Bah, whose son has been at the academy since it opened in 2006. "Now it's like they're dismantling everything."

The Highbridge Green School has been selected to showcase the Middle School Quality Initiative (MSQI) in the inaugural year of Chancellor Carmen Fariña’s Showcase Schools Program. The program is designed to promote collaboration and sharing of strong practices. Schools that excel in a specific learning focus area will host educators from other schools to share their successful structures and strategies. Read more here.
The school is located at 200 East 167th Street
Chalkbeat highlights a project by students at the Highbridge Green School in which they interviewed parents and community members about their immigration experiences. Read more here.
Students at Highbridge Green School do yoga before state exams to relieve stress. A science teacher with a background in neuroscience also leads meditation exercises. Read more here.

The Highbridge Green School was created thanks to the efforts of a parent group called The United Parents of Highbridge, and parents have continued to be highly involved in the school community since it opened in the fall of 2013. Now the school is grappling with the question of how to include the parents in the school's decision-making process in the future. Read more here.
Highbridge students trade after school time for tutoring as part of a pilot program attempting to raise the low reading levels of students. Read more here.
This is a really nice article.  Worth reading, especially for parents thinking about applying to the school next year.

The Highbridge Green School is piloting an extended day program that will give participating students the opportunity to get extra help with literacy and to participate in extracurricular activities. As the program gets underway, the school is troubleshooting solutions for increasing participation. Read more here.
I am so glad that i was chosen to go to such a wonder ful school like the highbridge green school i can't wait for this school year to begin.

The Highbridge Green School is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

Many people say bad things about this school, but it is not so bad. I feel as if the school would have been better if more opportunities were given to ALL the students. I was in the honor's class but it was not all that because there were some kids in the honor's class who, based upon their grades, honestly did not belong there. That was the bad thing. The good thing is that I was pushed to do my best, and took AP Spanish which helped me to get a college credit in Spanish, which was geat! I don't think there is any discrimination against non-honor students. Actually, non-honor students should feel lucky because they get to relax more and do not have to feel way to pressured like I felt sometimes, but it was worth it. So, downside is that the school needs to offer more activities. Also, they need more teachers and more subjects such as physics and another language besides Spanish. Not everyone wants to learn Spanish, even though it is good to learn due to it being a rising language. Another thing is that some of the staff need to be changed because many of them had really bad attitudes and disrespected the students. The principal needs to get himself together because before I left, he seemed to stop being seen and stopped calling the students winners. So, I don't know what was going on with him, but I hope he seems more excited about the school now. Medical detectors are good for safety, even though it was annoying sometimes. So, the school is not the most amazing school ever, but it is not the worst either. I think if opportunities can not be offered in school, the counselors should offer some outside resources that can helpful to ALL students. At least it does not have violence like TAFT had back in the days.  It seems much more safe. Good luck to whoever goes there, make friends, tell a counselor and your parents if you have problems, take advantage of any opportunities given to you, and don't give up!

"i think this school is a bit too strict."

"When I first went to this high school as a freshman I noticed a lot of violence and I also noticed this school had metal detectors. Every morning I had to take off my shoes, belt, and jewelry," writes student Olga. "If an educational establishment has to go through this every morning they are not treating this as a high school -- it's a prison!"

"Only the honor students get the benefits of the school while the other students are given poor teachers," a student writes. "The school could be better if all students are given the same opportunities."

The grandmother of a student at the school praised the principal: "My grandson is a special ed student and he [the principal] makes him feel good." She said that Principal WIlliam Quintana refers to the students as "doctor" which they like. "My principal has an open policy to parents -- I can go to him with any problem. He'll say, 'I'll look into it and get back to you.'"
"The school is there for you," said an 11th grade student named Michael, who was captain of the soccer team. "The school is dedicated to help us be what we want to be."

"The thing I would like to change is the perception that people have of the building," said Principal William Quintana, adding that while the building is quite safe, it is a challenge to overcome the reputation for disorder and violence that it had in the old days of Taft High School.

"This school is a great school," writes 9th grader, Shaquia. " This school gives you possibilities. I am also enrolled in an internship with Dr. Sat of the Harlem Children Society. This is a great opportunity for me. The school is very safe. The teachers are nice."

"I am so proud to be part of this school, writes student Diadji. "The people here really encourage you to do your best and really care about you. The teachers are great and it's a great learning environment."

"I think that this school is the best school I have ever attended," writes Joel L., a student. "The teachers and the staff are very nice. The thing that I like the most about the school is how we wear hunter green medical scrubs and sometimes Mr. Quintana, the principal of this great school, might greet us with 'Dr. _________.' Overall, I really love this school and I am happy I was chosen into this school."

"I personally like this school because it sets a high standard for the kids and I think that it's really good for them," writes Susan Coote, a parent. "This school shows interest in what the kids are doing and [they] really encourage them to pursue their dreams. This school really opened my daughter's eyes to face reality and not to waste her life."

A collaborative spirit and a unified hunger to make sure all students thrive, learn, and grow, Mott Hall continues to defy the odds.

Potential staff should beware of pursuing or accepting a position here. Some staff, those closely aligned with the administration, will have good experiences, but other staff leave (20-25% per year) to escape how they are treated. While this is not uncommon in NYC schools, do research and ask questions in the interviews to determine if this is the right place for you. Staff is micro-managed to the point of having little to no professional discretion, contractual benefits and rights are often disregarded, and select staff are routinely threatened, coerced, and spied on by the administration and their sycophants.

We teach a vulnerable population and as you have acknowledged, many schools in this community are struggling. Our success is not an accident; it represents the united spirit of our administration and staff. Our success is built on shared values, vision, and sacrifice for the benefit of the children we serve. 
Our Mott Hall kids don't need someone like you. 
Our Mott Hall kids deserve so much better than you. 
Our Mott Hall kids deserve someone who shows up EVERY day prepared to teach them, ready to collaborate with colleagues, and the humility to be a learner themselves. I wish you peace- not because you deserve it but because that is what is right. I certainly am at peace knowing you will do no further harm to my students and our school community.

Your figure of 20-25% is entirely inaccurate and misrepresents the decisions of staff members who were and continue to be respected members of the Mott Hall community despite moving on to new opportunities. For professionals who wish to engage with their colleagues and be challenged as pedagogues, there is no better place in NYC. Especially for beginning teachers, this community has been nothing but nurturing. Our scholars are growing and outpacing our peer schools because of our shared vision for teaching and learning, the support of our administration, and the solid commitment of our staff to put the needs of children before our egos. You do not represent this place "Concerned Professional."
Mott Hall 8th-grade math teacher Denise Clarke is a recipient of the 2015 Big Apple Award for excellence in teaching. Read more here.

The debate team recent beat rivals at Bronx High School of Science and Stuyvesant and are headed to the state championship in April, the Daily News reported. The debaters "incorporate Spanish, slam poetry and rap in their arguments, which throws off other teams and transforms the debate into a kind of performance," the Daily News said in an article Feb. 15, 2011.
"There are so many clubs," said one 7th grader. "I signed up for five yesterday."
"I like it," said a seventh grader. A downside he noted: "Sometimes it's hard because if you forget your homework in your locker you can't go back and get it."
"It's a real family at this school," said Principal Meisha Ross. "These are my kids. It has to be school where my daughter can go to." She added that the school is supported by Urban Assembly.
"There are a lot of opportunities here and you definitely get a workout attending here," said one student, referring to all the stairs.

"It's good, but I wanted a middle school basketball team, so the student government told me to write the names of students who will be on the team and to find a teacher to coach and then give it to the principal," said a 7th boy. "The student government is really good. They listen to us."
"The school is much better this year," said a group of graduating seniors, who noted that the new guidance counselors were incredibly helpful, and that "they motivate us."
"You pretty much know everyone. It's a small school," said one 9th grader.
"The student government is more assertive," said one senior. "They're making themselves known this year."
"[The library] must get on average 200-300 visits per day," said the school's librarian. "We get a lot of business."

Recent graduate Marquis Robinson writes, "This school is a close-knit family. Ms. Ross has become like a mother. The teachers are very intellectual and they teach you on a personal level. It has been a privilege to attend LGJ and be a mock trial state champ."
The school's mock trial team won a statewide championship, despite the personal challenges that took a toll on the team's members, according to the New York Daily News.

A student who transferred out of the school said, "Every few weeks there were new math teachers. They don't know you. You're only known by your ID number...The building is too crowded." She adds: "I wasn't challenged."

"I have been teaching in the NYC system since 1992 and I have never been happier teaching than now at LGJ," writes Samuel Noel. "We have wonderful kids, an outstanding faculty, and a caring administration. I highly recommend our school to students and parents. There's an energy here that's contagious. I teach AP English and when setting up a class of eleventh grade honors English, so many kids signed up for the extra work that we had to create an additional class. Our kids want to move forward to the next level!"

Teacher Roberta Lataille writes: "LGJ is an outstanding school for motivated young men and women. We offer a full stand-alone law curriculum and have recently added AP classes. The students are kind and warm. The administration truly cares about its students." She adds: "Applicants should be warned that they will not succeed at LGJ unless they work VERY hard. This is not a school for students who are not willing to put the time, enthusiasm, and effort into their endeavors."

A student complains: "[Attending HS 505] was my biggest mistake. I have been part of the student body since Sept. 2001 and this is my senior year. The school appears to be a beauty, but... the school's focus on 'discipline' has taken away from the academic aspect of an education." She also complains about the management style of the administration and staff.

"As an LGJ Senior, I can honestly say that, in my heart, no other school has the intelligent and ambitious students, nor the caring staff like Bronx Law," writes Shana P. "I look forward to going to school everyday because when I am there, it's not just going into a big building with classmates and school staff. When I walk into that building it's a home, with my family. And that is what makes Law, Government, and Justice so unique; our wonderful family-like atmosphere. This feeling comes alive the most the day before Thanksgiving break. That is when all of the LGJ students and staff bring food, drinks, snacks, etc, to the building and we have a Thanksgiving celebration feast with music and all. It saddens me to think that this school year is my final year, but I can only thank my principal and the rest of the LGJ staff for encouraging me, along with the other 2005 graduates, to be the best."
"I believe that this school is very open to students who want to succeed," writes Victoria A., a student. "It also has classes that has the student 'hands-on'."
Mount Eden Children's Academy has a roof top garden and a community center, DNAinfo reports. http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20130211/high-bridge/south-bronx-parents-fight-improve-district-9-schools

New Settlement Apartments, the respected community group, has opened a $100-million complex that includes an elementary school with a dance studio, a music room and a 75-foot swimming pool. http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/bronx/new-settlement-bronx-100-million-complex-schools-community-center-opens-article-1.1149182
TYWLS Bronx hopes its 2017-18 inaugural graduating class will attend college, Pix11 news reports.

Devon Eisenberg and LeMarie Laureano founded the Young Women's Leadership School of the Bronx together and continue to lead the school side by side as "co-directors." The two share an equal role in responsibilities, decisions and management. The mother of a 9th grader attending the school says the leadership of two female co-directors "shows young girls that two women can be bosses with a common goal. Children love to run but few elementary schools have track teams. But, the Riverdale Press reports, the Milton Fein School is an exception. In 2018 at the request of principal Miosotis Ramos, former high school track coach, and physical education teacher Anthony Hilliard began a running program for 4th and 5th graders in partnership with New York Road Runners, The team got off to a rocky start but Hilliard eventually developed a dedicated group of runners who have developed discipline as well as athletic skills.

Administrators and teachers at the Milton Fein School have implemented a new curriculum that teaches students how to recognize and manage their emotions, set and work toward personal goals, show empathy, form good relationships, and make responsible decisions. The goal, according to an article in the Riverdale Press is to improve classroom behavior, and in the process, academic performance.

My goal isnt to just write a laundry list of what I dont like, but to challenge myself to get more educated and involved so that things can get better. P.S. 20 P.O. George J. Werdan III is among 40 middle schools selected for an extension of the Middle School Quality Initiative, a program that increases professional development with Common Core-aligned literacy strategies and gives targeted funding for literacy training and materials. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

Because of improvements in its test scores, PS 20 was removed from the state's list of schools needing improvement and is now considered "in good standing" under No Child Left Behind.

"There isn't anything negative I can think of to say about this school," writes Alejandro, who graduated from 8th grade in 2003. "The building is very modern and everything from science supplies to desks are new. It had after school programs for students who were struggling in a subject and early morning programs for those trying to get into a specialized high school. There is a police precinct next door, so the the school is more than safe from violence. The teachers were extremely caring. They talked with students about their personal lives and helped them choose high schools."
PS 20 had the most health code violations in its kitchen of any school in the city, the New York Post reported on October 16, 2006. The school had 65 violations, mostly because of a mice problem.

At least 140 parents signed a letter in support of PS 24 principal Steven Schwartz in the wake of anonymous letters sharply critical of him, according to the Riverdale Press. The letter was the latest round in a series of controversies surrounding the school and its leadership.

With the help of two local historical societies, PS 24 is using the stories of blacks i the north Bronx, including the enslaved Africans who built the Van Cortlandt plantations,to teach black history, the Riverdale Press reports.

Steven Schwartz, principal of PS 24 in the Bronx, "is so eager for praise he offered a quid pro quo to teachers who show up at a public meeting next Tuesday to make their Riverdale school — and him — look good. PS 24 still does not have a new principal after the former principal resigned last fall amid controversy. Andrea Feldman remains the acting principal as the DOE continues to delay the hiring process. Read more here.

My son graduated PS 24 in 2014.  In 2014-15, he went to a private school, where he was quite far ahead of his classmates in math, straight 4s all year, and without having to do any extra work.  And my son was NOT in a G&T class at PS 24.  I really can't say enough about PS 24, I don't get the nay-sayers.  I mean, yes, it is a big public school, and that comes with challenges.  But the administration, staff and parent body are all very committed to their children's education, so the problems of a big school pale in comparison to the opportunity that exists at PS 24.  Any kid that wants to can get an incredible education at PS 24, regardless of background or income level.  Such a great community.

PS 24 hired a new instrumental music teacher, reports the Riverdale Press in the article PS 24 salvages its music program. The school excessed its instrumental and vocal teachers after the 2011-12 school year because of budget cuts but, because of a rise in enrollment, it found extra funds to support the much-loved music program.

the principal tried to "excess" the music teacher because the teacher wasn't good.  the principal would have replaced her the next year with a new teacher, but parents didn't catch on to the plan. too bad.  the "new" teacher was just the old teacher hired back.

That's a boat load of misinformation. The principal tried to excess two out of two music teachers and all of kindergarten paraprofessionals. It was all about the money. Music teachers were both competent and the one that didn't get rehired was universally loved. The administration's plan was to rely on fundraising efforts of PTA to plug those holes. As part PA's pitch at PS24 welcome picnic, incoming K parents are asked to donate $1K/family just to cover K teachers assistants.

no misinformation whatsoever - my son was attending PS 24 when this went down, so i know all about it, first hand.  and, you are confusing 2 issues.  the first issue is about the ways in which a principal can and cannot replace teachers, according to DOE and UFT rules.  the second has to do with budget shortfalls system-wide, not just at PS 24.  parents were asked for donations by the parent association - not the school! - for UP TO $1k, according to a family's available income.  some families gave $25, $50, whatever they could afford, and that was great...  whatever the amount, the purpose of those donations was to provide funds to hire kindergarten teachers' assistants , as you correctly state.  the school relied on the PA to raise those funds because the DOE is not providing enough funds to cover those costs, although enrollment continues to rise at all schools, system-wide.  PAs are doing this across the city, because their children benefit, and a public education is otherwise free!  and, the program was a success - extra teachers assistants were hired to help teach 8 kindergarten classes, up from 5 or 6 the year before!  another example of how the staff and parent body work together so beautifully at this school...

but the kindergarten fundraising program had nothing to do with the music teachers.  in that case, the administration was just trying to upgrade the music department staff.  the most direct path they saw was to take a year off from the music program, which would allow them to excess the music teachers, and reapply the funds elsewhere.  then the following year, they could reallocate money for an all new music department and start fresh with new teachers.  but because the parents reacted so strongly,  the admin retreated and rehired the same teachers.  whether this was the right or wrong way to go about trying to renew the music program can be debated, but everyone should realize it was done with the intention of ultimately providing a BETTER music program.  if you look at all of the other improvements in the arts programs and elsewhere at the school since this administration took over, it's obvious that they were just trying to upgrade the music program as well, not to take it away permanently.

I will give you benefit of the doubt, although it's not at all what the administration presented to the school about the music teachers. They said that they will rely on outside non-profits exclusively as a way to have music at school, and if PA wants to supplement, they were welcome to raise funds. Ironically, none of these outside programs is supposed to function without a permanent music teacher, and once two of them both threatened to walk and take away the instruments they donated, the principal reinstated one teacher. There is no better music program, a three  years later. 

As far as K, assistant principal said to many parents who complained that paras don't make money for the school, and most schools in the city don't have K assistants, and canned all of them. Of course, donations to the TA fund are not mandatory - that would be illegal. But it was made clear to us that if we don't donate, our kids will have one adult in the classroom. Which they still did, for half the day.

Yeah, they kind of had to present it that way... They couldn't say they were trying to replace teachers, there would have been massive blowback.  You would not believe the resistance they have encountered trying to make improvements at that school...

PS 24 parents "band" together to try and save the school's music program after both music teachers were let go because of budget cuts, reports The Riverdale Press. Read more: http://riverdalepress.com/stories/Parents-band-together-to-save-music-program,50711

PS 24 has cut the two school's two full-time music instructors and a kindergarten teacher in response to budget cuts, reports The Riverdale Press. The assistant principal says he is committed to finding new ways to integrate music, like community partnerships. "Music is not going to die at PS 24," he told The Riverdale Press.

You don't have to live in Riverdale to go to PS 24. It's just that there are rarely any spaces for kids living outside of the zone who aren't special ed/G&T students.

What does that even mean? It's a zoned school, so you do have to live in Riverdale. You also can try for G&T if you live in D 10, and then you can go there if you qualify. That's the law, that's the rule. Elementary schools in NYC are zoned.

I graduated from ps24 in 08. A lot of us in the accelerated class ended up in stuyvesant, hunter, bronx science, or lehman's high school of american studies.
 ps24 was amazing and I didn't realize at the time how fortunate we were to have a planetarium, an art studio, and cool events like springfest and the dance festival. Lastly, if someone says the accelerated classes aren't challenging they are misinformed are lying. In fourth grade we had to read New York Times articles (about two to three a day) and respond to at least 5 questions for each. I stay up as late doing stuy hw as i did in fourth grade.
However, I graduated the year mr. sharpener (horrible inside joke) became principal so i dont know if the new administrations have lowered the standards.
P.S. 24 is doing a great job at bringing the majority of the pupils (many with special needs) up to the minimum state standards.
